description:
First time at this long needed kiosk outside the Ferry Building. My cappuccino was perfect and I was so eager for that first sip, I messed up my heart before taking that gratuitous coffee selfie. :)

The baristas are super friendly and efficient. Meanwhile the storefront in the building streamed long lines. 

Drink coffee, local coffee. Caffeine makes the world go round, prevents world wars and just makes the weekend all so much yummier!
author: Carlyn C.

description:
This is a must-visit every time I'm at the Ferry Building. Their coffee is so good! My go-to drink is their New Orleans, which they also sell in cartons at Costco or Whole Foods. It's amazing when consumed freshly made. Their affogato (expresso over a scoop of coffee ice cream) was amazing even at 8am!

Don't let the long line deter you from checking this place out if you've never been as the line does move relatively quickly.
author: Tim Y.

description: Bluebottle makes great coffee! This kiosk is great it's outside the ferry building instead of inside the ferry building. The one that is inside the ferry building has a huge line and this one has no line! I always thoroughly enjoy my decaf Americano.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This is the no-fuss Blue Bottle that exists mostly for the tourists who take their mandatory Bay Bridge photos at the Ferry Building. But locals like me can also get their fix here because the line never seems as long here as it does inside. As true Blue Bottle aficionados know, ambiance is key to the appeal of their stores, and the outdoor arcade has an architectural appeal about it. It also helps that you don't have to fight the crowds inside the building on a busy weekend. All bets are off, however, when the Farmers Market is happening and foot traffic multiplies. I try to avoid the area then as I'm usually here waiting to meet Jamie W. and want some kind of libation.

More often than not, I have ordered the $4 Iced Cold Brew just because the al fresco setting lends itself to something cold and refreshing (photo: http://bit.ly/2wZ2pRz). Besides it's not as calorific as the New Orleans Iced Coffee which comes in that milk carton where I keep looking for a photo of a lost child. I'm not sure if they make their Belgian waffles, affogatos, or other acts of decadence here anymore, but it's just as well I don't know as I don't need those calories either. I usually take it to go since Jamie isn't much of a coffee drinker, and we just stroll the waterfront on sunny weekends. Nice to know I have this quality caffeine option in such a tourist-infested area.

COFFEE - 4 stars...mostly iced, mostly Blue Bottle quality
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...on a sunny day, just fine...on a not-so-sunny day, still good
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...surprisingly faster than the other stores in the chain
TOTAL - 4 stars...this arcade is indeed a true arcadia
author: Ed U.

description:
Nice coffee shop located in the Ferry building. There are several locations in downtown SF which is nice as well.

Simple menu that includes mocha, drip coffee, latte, and etc. Decently priced $4-$6

Staff was fast and friendly.

Ordered an iced mocha and it was really good. Good coffee taste along with nice cocoa, not artifical chocolate taste at all. Definitely would get my coffee here when I'm in the area. Quality coffee shop!
author: Michele G.

description: My favorites are the Iced Latte and the New Orleans Style iced coffee. I like the hints of vanilla in their drinks and their logo is probably my favorite logo out of all the best coffee spots in SF. I especially like this location because I like sitting on my favorite bench outside of the ferry building and people watch! For snacks, my favorites are the ginger molasses cookie or the WAFFLE.
author: Andrea T.

description: This coffee was a little more nutty flavor than I prefer but I am taking time to write this review because of the non-coffee selection on their menu. I have a friend who is unable to drink coffee for medical reasons, they can't even drink decaf. so when I happened upon this little spot and found out that they served chicory "coffee" I decided to give them my business... because, I love when niche spots carry a more than typical menu. blue bottle has definitely gone out of their way to do that. I had the chicory just for the heck of it and an iced latte. both were decent but like I said before, they highlighted flavors that aren't my preference for coffee. even still, shout out to them for making things accessible for all.
author: Rucinda S.

description: Great local coffee and staff that love it as well.  I wish they served more than one size since coffee is my favorite addiction.  Great place to try coffee that started in SF.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I'm not a coffee lover and was actually expecting this place to be just overrated. We were in line for about 15mins and maybe 5 or more to get our coffee. The Americano was really strong and tasted good.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee has two locations inside the Ferry Building, hence the two listings on Yelp. This location is a corner stall located on the north end of the building. There are two counters to order from. The other location can be found across the arcade closer to the main entrance of the building. That location has a tasting room which features flights of coffee (and heated seats). Both locations offer espresso drinks, pour over coffee, and pastries.

Blue Bottle is based across the bay in Oakland. The company is known for its high quality single-origin coffee which is prepared in small batches. It's a shining example of "third wave coffee" which is pretty much gourmet artisanal coffee where special attention is paid to each and every step of the coffee-making process, from sourcing to roasting to preparation. Coffee connoisseurs (and hipsters/snobs) love this place.

The menu at the stand was short and sweet:

* House espresso (Hayes Valley) and single-origin espresso - $3 each
* Macchiato - $3.50
* Cappuccino - $4.00
* Caffe latte - $4.50
* Caffe mocha - $5.00
* Affogato (espresso over ice cream) - $5.50
* Drip coffee: Three Africas - $3.50, Ethiopia - $4.50
* Cold brew iced coffee: Three Africas - $4.00, New Orleans - $4.00
* Almond milk added to any drink - $1.00
* Cascara fizz (cascara syrup, soda, lemon) - $4.00
* Samovar tea - $3.00
* Hot chocolate (made with TCHO chocolate) - $4.00
* Liege Wafel - $4.00

I had a latte with almond milk and it was delicious. The coffee tasted like it was meticulously prepared from organic direct-trade beans supplied by a lone farmer and his specific harvest micro lot. Just kidding. I have no idea what I'm talking about. I like coffee, but am no connoisseur nor do I have a discerning palate for specialty coffees. Generally, coffee from chains will make me just as satisfied as the latte I had here, which was quite good (warm and it hit the spot). It even came with one of those artistic leafy designs on top.

If you're visiting the Ferry Building and/or Embarcadero and want a cup of coffee or need some caffeine, Blue Bottle is definitely worth checking out.

Great service.

Outside of the Bay Area, Blue Bottle Cafes can be found in New York, LA, and Tokyo.
author: Daniel B.

description:
SERVED FAST AND ACCOMMODATING SERVERS. Got my usual favorite affogato and while I waited for my coffee the servers lead a polite conversation to past the time and most people don't take the unnecessary effort to do this or are too busy. There wasn't a line when I got there so was served extremely fast. Love this place. 

Personally, my tastebuds prefer sweet and are not use to the bitter authentic coffee so each time I get an affogato it kinda taste like trash but the good kind of trash. So I definitely recommend an affogato.
author: Teresa L.

description:
Thumbs up for having a blue bottle here!!

They are the kings of cappuccino!
author: Deebs M.

description: I had capuccino and it is GREAT.  I would like to  buy some ground coffe but only small packages are available which is a pity for me.
author: Clare G.

description: Blue Bottle has been one of my favorite coffees. I love Giant Steps. I always come here when I'm in the city and stock up. I found that I can sometimes buy it at Whole Foods too. My only concern is that I understand they were bought by Nestle. I'm hoping the quality stays the same. I tend to stay with smaller local companies so this makes me a little sad.
author: Sheri M.

description: Good iced coffee from a quick take out stand. No line when I went in the morning on a weekday. Price seems steep for an iced coffee, but that's to be expected in SF - maybe I'd try a latte next time.
author: Winnie Y.

description: Excellent coffee, friendly service. The ferry building is an interesting place for a shop. This is a well-known tourist place, which means that it is usually crowded.
author: Lucy M.

description:
The service was great, because a good looking guy had a bright, nice attitude (I forgot what his name was), and the second after I ordered & asked "Um, where do I wait to get my drink?" (Since it was my first time being at the place, I didn't know where I'm allowed to stand) a short black haired lady working behind him placed my drink in front of me. That was literally the quickest service I have ever received in my life...but I don't go out as much though, now that I think of about it. Lol. 

I got the New Orleans Iced Coffee, and as a someone who is a "non-coffee drinker/ more of a sweets person who would usually prefer sugary drinks than bitter stuff like Starbucks" this drink is not for me but it's not bad at all. I challenged myself to NOT to add anything to the drink, and to just consume it all straight and I gotta admit, it's pretty good if I were to be a coffee drinker. Love the pure taste of it, not watered down or "too bitter". It does has a bitter aftertaste but it was very light. Would get it again as a coffee drinker I guess but as how I am, no but I would definitely try out their other drinks. Worth trying out!
author: Emi G.

description:
All I could taste in my $4 cold brew coffee was sourness. If a good coffee is supposed to be this sour, I don't want coffee to be part of my life. 

The line moved quickly and people were nice.
author: Jorge T.

description:
We had a somewhat interesting ordering experience here. Let's just say it was a little snobby and pretentious. My husband ordered a decaf cappuccino and asked for a Splenda. I don't remember what size he ordered, but I think he asked for the smallest size (8 or 12 oz).  The hipster cashier lady said, "We don't have that size for that drink" without suggesting an available size for his drink. So my husband asked for whatever the next size up is. The hipster cashier lady replied, "We don't have Splenda, we only have organic cane sugar" without asking if he would like that instead. So my said sure, he'll have that. Lines were long within five minutes of opening, and even longer by the time my husband received his drink. 

Overall: This location is very touristy. Blue Bottle overall is extremely hipster and trendy, very into organic everything. It's not for everyone.

Tip for Chase Sapphire Preferred and Reserve cardholders: Places that use Square to process payments usually do not process your purchases as Dining (confirmed by Chase customer service) so you will not receive your bonus earn. I found out the hard way :(. However, my transaction here processed as Dining even though this location uses Square. Not sure what to make of it.
author: Di W.

description: The staff was very kind and received the coffe fast but it was just okay. The atmosphere was pretty nice and the price wasn't high though.
author: Jaxon H.

description: The best coffee and other drinks in the city, as well as the atmosphere that always heats. Barista was very friendly and helpful. I recommend.
author: Simon A.

description: Perhaps it's a bit overrated. They have good coffee but nothing spectacular. Their cold brew was just as good as the one I make myself at home. Prices are fair I guess compared to how touristy it is.
author: Jenine G.

description: Amazing service! So quick and they even gave us a sample! I was shocked with how quick it came out even though it was on a Saturday during the farmers market. Shoutout to Rayson for being such a nice cashier and barista!
author: Jana Z.

description:
Seriously ... this is THE BEST Mocha I've ever had.  Everytime I come to the City and hit the Ferry Building I always have to stand in the ridiculously long line to get one of these. YUM! I'll admit, I'm not much of a plain coffee drinker unless I'm at a diner for breakfast but I do love me some good foo foo coffee.  However it does need to be strong and not too sweet which is exactly how Blue Bottle makes their mochas.  By the way, for you hipsters, Blue Bottle is a Pour Over coffee joint which I hear is what makes it extra special.  Whatever it is, it's freakin delicious and I wish they'd open one in Downtown San Jose. 

There's several Blue Bottle Coffee Stands around SF and I see many shops in the Bay Area carry the brand but nothing compares to being in the Ferry Building and sipping this warm, delicious cup of Joe.
author: Christie B.

description: Received the wrong order after watching people who came after me get theirs. The two gossiping baristas could not have cared less, as a matter of fact, the only person who gave a crap was the dude that was doing the drip coffee. He reimbursed me and offered to make me the correct order. To management, this guy is gold, everyone else not so much.
author: Marcos B.

description:
Great coffee, you can taste the quality!!! 
There are two sides to this stand and the one near the restroom is always shorter!!
I got their cappuccino and that perked me right up!
author: Heidi L.

description: Always excellent. Memorably delicious. Latte, Macchiato, Gibraltar, whatever. Ferry Building fun, outdoor bench, view of bay & Blue Bottle in hand can't be beat....
author: Harley M.

description:
On Saturdays, during Farmers Market in the Ferry Building, you know darn well lots of crowd congregate here. 

They migrate here like a flock of seagulls all lining up to get some Porchetta at the Roli Roti Gourmet Rotisserie or some additively bomb ass Chicharrones from 4505 Meats. Equally as addictive is any coffee concoction they make at Blue Bottle. It's either a New Orleans-style Iced Coffee or a Soy Latte for me. 

Their main location is inside the Ferry Building right across from Ciao Bella Gelato. Even though that location has two lines, those lines tend to snake around like there's no tomorrow. So if you're impatient and smart like me, avoid that location and head on towards their two coffee stands outside the building. 

One is near the southern front entrance of the building facing Embarcadero. Another one located on the southern corner near the side entrance of the building, usually across from Roli Roti. I don't know why it is, but these two coffee stands are faster than their main location on Saturdays. 

These guys know exactly what they're doing; it's simple supply and demand. I demand their coffee, they supply it to me ASAP. 

So avoid the main location on Saturdays and head on to their two coffee stands. Unless you are the kind of person that likes standing in long lines so you can stay connected in the cyber world on your smart phones with your various social media account profile, then go ahead so people like me can avoid staying connected.

I'll drink my Soy Latte and Iced Coffee to that.
author: John G.

description: This is the best cappuccino i have ever had.... some people complain about price, but when your coffee is flawless it should be pricey! Some people complained about the line but I walked straight up and got my coffee within a minute of waiting. Customer service was outstanding, employees had great attitudes, and the brand it set in stone! Great place.... I wish I could go here everyday. I went twice in one day! Heading back to my hometown. I also got lucky with the line, but I went at open and right before closing.
author: Rachel C.

description:
This is located on the embarcadero side of the ferry building. Useful for when you just want coffee and aren't interested in the line at the blue bottle location inside the ferry building. Because it's a walk up, it doesn't have the range of pastry options other locations have. You will basically be restricted to four-five choices which vary daily but could best be described as what you see is what you get.
The coffee products are the exact same quality that you find at any blue bottle, but with half the wait. Awesome for when you are in a hurry.
There's a few picnic tables across from the ordering/delivery window and while they do offer shelter from the sun and rain, they are not the epitome of luxury. Also at times the staff won't be especially diligent about keeping the coffee additives(located outside the walkup on a bench)-creamer, sugar, sugar substitute et al. as stocked up as it could be.It's no trouble to ask for what you don't see at the counter though.
Still the best and quickest option if you are wanting some basic blue bottle goodness in a line free enviroment.
author: Steven W.

description: I got the new orleans cold brew. Ive had better coffee and to charge $4 for a small cup of what tasted like watered down coffee is a rip off. Maybe I ordered the wrong coffee but it didnt taste like anything special to me.
author: Prima Z.

description: I was visiting from Los Angeles and deliberately avoided going to Starbucks while I was here because of all of the coffee shops in this city. Specifically I had heard about how great blue bottle was and I was excited to try it. I played it safe and got one of the cold brew options (single origin) and enjoyed it. The staff were nice and it was easy to pay with a card with the Square.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Post-lunch + drip coffee at Blue Bottle farmers market stand + people watching =

Best combo ever.

That's all I have to say about that.
author: Sandee T.

description:
This globetrotter is once again back home(ish) in the Bay Area for important matters, and no - I don't mean just food - but of course food is always important!  Day one of my weeklong vacation was an exciting day in downtown San Francisco with a fellow Californian from school.  I had to pay my dues, as a loss a bet last semester, so our first stop was In-N-Out Burger.  It may seem like an ordinary place to eat - but not when you live across the ocean!

I decided to be touristy, so we made our way to the Ferry Building for some Blue Bottle Coffee, one of San Francisco's famous coffee roasters.  They have several locations across San Francisco, but I'd have to say my most frequented would be the one located in the Ferry Building (Embarcardero), because there you also have access to Miette's delicious macarons!

Blue Bottle offers a variety of organic, non-pesticide beans, as well as coffee gadgets to brew your coffee just the way you like.  They also offer those options in-shop, and I hear the New Orleans Iced Coffee is their celebrity, but I have yet to try it.  So far, I've had their regular latte, which is a smooth and lightly aromatic.  It's not the strongest, nor the darkest, but it isn't acidic, and is very satisfying in both aroma and flavor.  Expensive for California (or the U.S., rather), I can see why one would cringe at paying almost $4 for a cup of coffee, but it's worth the experience!

The downsides of the Ferry Building location is the lack of seating and privacy if you're looking to have an intimate chat - but it's definitely the perfect place for a coffee to warm the soul in this always-chilly city.
author: Tammy L.

description:
The line is sooooooooooooooo long.

Not to worry though, it moves reeeeeeeaaaaaaal fast.

And when you get to the display case where various coffee contraptions, newly re-popularized in the US but used extensively in other countries, the line gets downright swift! 

Cafe Mocha was soooooooooooooo good.

Hot Chocolate for kids is brewed at a lower temperature.

Hot chocolate for adults is awesomely rich.

Drip coffee had no aftertaste. Yes!

Service is quick, friendly, and very accomodating.
author: Kislev A.

description:
I did not try the coffee but it smelled amazing. I ordered a hot chocolate and it was scrumptious. It pretty much tasted like I was drinking (eating) a very high quality chocolate bar. It wasn't too sweet and had just the right mix of milk and chocolate.
On another note, on a Sunday afternoon we waited over 30 minutes in line to get our drinks. Was it worth a 30 minute wait? Probably night but if you have time to chill out it will be a delicious treat.
author: Schelly Y.

description: There are a couple of Blue Bottle stands at the Farmers' Market at the Ferry Building on Saturdays.  I picked one and got into the long line.  My CAPPUCCINO was excellent and a great way to end my Farmers' Market outing during my recent trip.
author: Carol L.

description:
I'm not a fan of coffee and don't know anything about coffee, but I come here for one reason: AFFOGATO!

It's 2 scoops of Humphrey Slocomb (the falvors change from time to time) topped with blue bottle espresso! The ice cream flavor varies from time to time but so far they all have been good!  Can't go wrong with Humphrey Slocomb local ice cream!
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
Went here on my first day in SF. Was nearly scared off by the queue, but soon came to realize that San Franciscans have queuing in their DNA. 
Oh. My. God. I had the single best coffee I have ever had in my life at Blue Bottle. I may have gotten a little emotional at just how perfect my cafe latte was. Pulled myself together though (no-one likes to see a large, hairy not quite middle aged man cry in public) enough to try the waffle that had just been cooked for me. Again with the emotional stuff. 5 stars aren't enough. Holy crap- eleventy gazillion stars aren't enough. Join the queue. It's more than worth it.
author: Matt H.

description:
One of the satellite BBC stands outside during the farmers market. Stand in a line that is a fraction of the one inside and get just as great coffee. I love this place!

Definitely get the iced coffee on a hot day but don't cheat yourself, treat yourself to a cappuccino during a chilly morning. 

Sometimes the outdoor locations are guilty of running out on stirrers and simple syrup, otherwise, perfection.
author: Anh T.

description:
Line is long, but moves pretty fast.
You'll be in and out around 10-20 mins tops.

I love their iced coffee.
Smooth with a nice strong taste.

There are a few blue bottle coffees all around San Francisco.
author: Missy W.

description: Always a lot of love for Blue Bottle.  Their coffee is just fantastic.  Though they have the permanent store inside the Ferry Building, you can find the stand outside on the opposite end of the Ferry Building on Saturdays.  This was my first time at the stand since I wanted my coffee now!  The line was a bit long, but it moved reasonably fast.  The baristas were taking orders ahead of payment to speed things up.  I really love the customer service here, they really took the time to make sure they got orders right and remembered who ordered what, that is just not an easy task.  Sometimes there might be mistakes here and there, but at least they make the attempt and take it one step further.  They're very efficient in handling the demand, but still keep that same quality of great coffee!
author: Bryson L.

description: The New Orleans Iced Coffee just wasn't for me. It was bitter tasting and not sweet at all. Wondering if I got a bad cup.
author: Jane H.

description:
Solid performance! 

We're always in search of good coffee and the folks at Blue Bottle have it in spades. In the space of two days, we tried their macchiato, brewed coffee, and soy lattes. All of the above were delish, but I have to lavish praise on the brewed coffee. I had the Three Africans and it was so over-the-top delicious that even someone with an under-developed coffee palate like myself (or most of us, really) could tell that this was a special thing- it tasted so clean, balanced, and didn't have a hint of burn to it. Well done!
author: Jon W.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee came recommended to me. Even if it wasn't, the line at the Ferry Building location made it clear it was recommended to a bunch of people - this is one popular spot. Asked for their drip coffee, then snagged a seat while a friend graciously picked up my order.

Their drip coffee is individually-prepared, taking several minutes to make a cup. Wholesome, with a woodsy taste, a cup will keep you up until the cows come home. (At least, it did the trick for me.) Worth the cost? Certainly.

Around the Embarcadero? Hit them up!
author: Dave L.

description:
After a failed attempt to get a cup of coffee in the Ferry Building, as seeing a huge lineup constitutes to me not wanting whatever your serving, and also because I was on vacation, and I'm not using line-up time to dwindle the time of fun I have in a certain place, I was lucky enough to find this stand sitting outside, and luckily catching it at a point where there wasn't much of a line-up!

I have had Blue Bottle coffee last year, and it was good, but I forgot how good it was. I had Ritual the day before, and that was pretty good, but with all the hype of Blue Bottle (Yes, we hear about this coffee from Vancouver too), I had to put my money down to know how good it was again. I didn't want to wait for the drip, and just ordered my Americano.... I was impressed, I have my coffee black, and that aroma, smoothness, non-bitter perfect blend of hot water going over those coffee beans, I can't say enough, or even put into words how good this coffee is. Let's just say I ended up back in line to purchase a small bag of beans for my trip home, and this time I waited as the line magically appeared, as it should.

This is one of the best coffee's I have had, period. The hype is real, you can't fool people for so long until something new comes around, and frankly there is no fooling, new coffee beans have popped up, and still Blue Bottle is leading the way. My bag of beans is sitting on my kitchen counter, waiting for the day I start drinking it, but it's not like I can just go out and get more beans. San Francisco, you guys are real lucky to have this premium java in your backyard!
author: Simon K.

description: Waaaay overrated and pricey. The coffee is good but, in no way, worth wait or the price. I would recommend they change up their routine to move the line faster. That would definitely improve the experience.
author: Brandon V.

description:
Blue Bottle Co. is definitely one of the better coffee places in SF. Just a warning, the location at the Ferry Building gets really crowded and you might need to wait in line for awhile to get your coffee fix. Tried the Gibraltar, latte, cappuccino. Very flavorful and rich coffee. 

What I recommend:

Cappuccino
author: Andrew W.

description:
The line was very very long.... the mocha wasn't all that spectacular. and it was pretty expensive, too. not like i would refuse to get coffee here ever, but would probably try sth else.

pretty latte art though.
author: Diana C.

description:
Im not the biggest fan of coffee, so I don't know what's good and what's not. People may think this is the best coffees on the planet, but I wouldn't know. 

I got the iced coffees, the wife got the drip. I don't think she enjoyed it as much as she should have, I think she regretted not getting cappuccino, so that affected her enjoyment. My coffee was cool.

I did enjoy the guy behind the counter. As first timers, he explained each an every item, even with the line growing behind us. You know what, Im giving it an extra star for that, now that I think of it(my original review was a 3)
author: renje g.

description:
I've been coming to the Ferry Building a lot these days, and since I was in the neighborhood in the morning, I decided to pick up my cop of joe here.

Their line was long, but they were quite fast! I got my favorite - the caffe latte, and it was delicious! Super smooth and creamy, but still light.

Once you have Blue Bottle, it's so hard to have to settle for Starbucks when there is no Blue Bottle around, oh man!!!
author: Veronica S.

description:
I LOVE you Blue Bottle!! Won't you consider opening up in the richmond district so I don't have to go into crowded downtown or Embarcadero to get my fix? 

Blue bottle is still my favorite strong coffee for when I need it most on those mornings where I'm dreading having to deal with the rest of the world and all it's let downs . I usually get a latte and ask for 2% milk which they do by combining non fat with whole milk. The cute little designes they make with the foam is also a nice touch! :)

The only thing I don't like about this location is the lines can get pretty long in the morning. Oh wells.
author: Petra S.

description:
I'm sorry to all the coffee aficionados, I apologize, we just didn't get it at all.

Recommended by friends home in the islands, so hey let's get in line before it gets longer. As we're standing, and standing, AND STANDING in line.... I'm wondering how long does it take to make good coffee? Starbucks, Peetes, Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf, and countless others crank out better coffee than this in a fraction of the time we waited.
 
So after waiting 40 minutes (I timed it...really) we got a cappuccino, and a macchiato that wasn't anywhere near hot, in two cyuuuuuuuute little teeny weeny coffee cups, the likes our girls used to play tea party with when they were babies. It was so tiny and soooo not hot, it was a chore not to gulp it down, holy moley I've seen Tequila shots that were bigger.

 Suffice to say okay.... seen it.... done it..... probably won't do it again.... I can get wired better on Patrone anyway.

  Sorry again aficionados, just speaking my piece.
author: Joe K.

description: I recently wrapped up a visit to San Fran and had to try Blue Bottle after hearing so many great things. All I can say is this coffee was worth the mighty long wait. Real good--one of the best cups I've ever had. I wish I had more time to try some of the other popular cafes during the trip to compare. But based on my limited sample, I would say Blue Bottle produces a darn good cup of joe.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Great coffee, worth every minute in line! 
I don't know what kind of magic they do to those beans, and what kind of fairy touched their baristas but that coffee is magic!
author: Marianna K.

description:
**CAFFE MOCHA HAD ME CREAMING and SCREAMING**

I don't drink coffee, but when I do, it has to be from Blue Bottle.

15 minute wait on a Saturday afternoon.

The Caffe Mocha with TCHO chocolate ($4.75) was . . .

 INSANELY delicious.

Light taste coffee with a hint chocolate.

PLAIN GOOD.

Downed the whole cup in 30 seconds.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
author: Betty N.

description:
I'm also tempted to go two stars on this one, but I'll round up. 

It wasn't bad. It just wasn't good.

The coffee was a touch roasty, which obviously appeals to a lot of people (charbucks) but I was hoping for something a bit more third wave. 

These guys have become the establishment, and apparently that comes with roasting a touch darker and using a La Marzocco Linea on the line...

They do have other shops with more inventive equipment, this location even has a Kees Spirit at the side window, but it wasn't open at the time I went. 

In my San Francisco coffee ratings, these guys are pretty far down the list...

Four Barrel, Wrecking Ball, Ritual, Saint Frank, Sightglass, Philz, Blue Bottle, Starbucks?? or something like that. 

I do love their Oakland roasting location's vibe, but the coffee is the same.
author: Jeremy M.

description: Nothing says "Perfect" more than getting your Cafe Latte from the cart right around 8am and then walking around the Farmer's Market before the tourists wake up and make their way to the area.  It is quite possibly one of my most favorite past times since moving here to SOMA.  Yeah the line's long, and if you show up at 9am, you will be waiting at least 30 minutes.  But, the hipster dudes that make my latte are always nice (not unlike the jerks at the shop inside the building who hate the fact that you exist), and its my favorite way to spend a Saturday morning!
author: Lisa I.

description: I love this coffee. Wish they would expand to DC. I am daily die hard Starbucks fan but would switch in a heartbeat to the blue bottle
author: Christina O.

description:
In a world where Starbucks and other mass coffee chains have taken over, it's refreshing to try a place that sells suuuuper good coffee at a decently more affordable price. Although it's still pretty pricey and several locations can be found all over SF, this is seriously one of the best coffees I've EVER tried! 

Because it was a hot day at the Farmer's market down at the Ferry building, my fiance and I tried their iced coffee. It was sooo good - had a nice strong coffee flavor, wasn't too sweet, and was served with some organic Clover soymilk. Yum! We really wanted to try their lattes, but it was just way too hot! :( Maybe next time!!
author: Nancy T.

description:
Can't believe how long the lines are! It does move somewhat slowly since they don't mass produce the coffee but it is good! 

We got the:
New Orleans style iced coffee - very flavorful
Cafe au lait - very smooth

I'm no expert, but this coffee was good!
author: Joy H.

description:
Hm. I didn't know what this was, but my brother raved about it and I saw a big line, so we got in line. It took a buttload of time to get to the front (they take their sweet time serving the customer) but I guess that's OK if you're not in a hurry. It gave us some time to make small talk and people watch.

I have to preface this by saying that I'm not the biggest coffee drinker in the world. I can tell the difference between motel coffee and Peets, but I'm not someone who thinks Starbucks is disgusting because "I brew such a better pot at home". I enjoy drinking coffee, but I'm in no ways a connoisseur. 

Which leads to me say... I don't get it. Yes, the coffee was solid and it was reasonably priced ($2-$5) but the Latte that I got didn't blow my mind. Definitely not worth waiting in line for, unless I have time to kill. 

Yeah. I'm sure some people are gonna call me an ignorant Starbucks loving prostitute, but I don't see the big appeal.

Still giving it 4 stars because the coffee tasted good and the people were friendly.
author: Takeo T.

description:
Cappuccinos only come in one size.  No clue why.

I had black coffee which surprisingly took longer than Lora's cappuccino which is an obvious proof that my cup of Joe is kind of awesome-tasting because of the intricate process and the nutty aroma that filled the air, how bold it was, it was not bitter... 

Hmmm.. If you are a Starbucks and/or a Peet's drinkers.. you have yet to experience coffee in its own art form.
author: Tram N.

description: I've been here so many times and yes the line for the coffee can suck. But it me it's worth the wait. The decaf is frothy, smooth and probably the best boldest decaf I've ever had. I have to hold back and not slurp it down in one swig...it's not a shot. But it's that smooth. And if I can't make it to the Ferry Bldg. they now serve it at Sideboard in Danville right in my backyard! I'm so spoiled :-)
author: Susan D.

description:
A general rule of thumb when I travel is to not have anything I can have at home.  In other words, no McFast Food, and no Starbucks.  That being said, I still need caffeine in order to function as a human being, and while out in San Francisco, I wanted to try something somewhat unique to the area.

I got off on Embarcadero, because I feared that if I stayed on BART any longer, I'd end up in big scary Oakland.  And then I punched in "coffee" on Google maps, and began walking towards the coast before the results tabulated.  Before I knew it, I was at the Ferry Building, and Blue Bottle was practically in front of me.

I must've been either ahead of the rush, or right after it, because there was no epic lines that others have cited; this was on a Monday morning at around 9 a.m. no less, so who knows, maybe I just got lucky.

I'm superstitious about the caffeine content of fancy drinks, so I stuck with the drip coffee, which is made to order at Blue Bottle.  It takes a little bit longer, but you're assured a fresh cup of coffee that you know hasn't been sitting pre-brewed for god knows how long.  But it's delicious, and tastes smooth and not like nuclear earth piss that makes you jittery.  It's like what I expected Starbucks blonde roasts to taste like when it released.

But the waffles there; I had eaten not long before, but when I saw these big fat waffles emerging from their back, I knew I had to find some extra stomach space in order to try one of these bad boys out.  And despite the bursting seam feeling in the pants (at the waist, not the goods, perv...although now that you mention it, they were pretty good waffles), it was worth the extra gluttony.

Overall a positive experience with Blue Bottle.  The coffee was smooth and good, and the waffles are to kill for.  They were an easy walk from Embarcadero BART, and a perfect spot to fuel up for a nice stroll down the piers to the Wharf and Golden Gate tour touristy types like myself.
author: Danny H.

description:
Solid beautiful day in SF. 
The sun was ablazing after the morning clouds dissipated.
But, enough of the weather report...

I took a stroll to Blue Bottle and ordered up a single latte.
The line wasn't too bad. 
I was the eighth caffeine-addict in line.

My latte was creamy and satisfying.
The brew was medium-high in intensity.
I keep forgetting to order a belgian waffle...dammit.

These guys have a wonderful formula worked to perfection.
There are actually two lines at this location.
Not sure if they are any different...I'm assuming not.
author: Derek N.

description:
Super nice staff, excellent coffee..what more can I say? All these Yelpers can give more insight than I can.

This stand can be a little bit less busy than the actual shop inside of the ferry building.
author: Alice C.

description:
Just like every Blue Bottle Coffee, this one is pretty awesome.

I don't normally drink ice coffee without sugar and cream, but the New Orleans Style iced coffee here is pretty amazing to the point of not needing a dang thing.  The espresso based drinks are traditional size (Euro size) but since they stick to the traditional theme it turns out pretty yummy, forget your 20 oz milky beverage with 2 shots of espresso when you can a few ozs of some high quality espresso. 

The caffe macchiato is one highlight I love, almost like being in Europe again with the creame at the bottom, one of these for lounging there and a NO iced coffee for the road means I m highly caffeinated for the next few hours.

I miss SF, someday I will find a job that I can move back to the Bay Area and enjoy this on a regular basis.
author: Tom Y.

description:
The unsweetened ice coffee was sooo strong...!
I love it!
author: Vivian G.

description:
Just thought about coffee and had to dream about the Blue Bottle..

One of the best strong, smooth, coffees that I have ever tasted!  LOVE the fact that they  drip the coffee individually, rather than a big pot.  The cappuccino is definitely small but you don't need much to get that caffeine kick.  The line is definitely worth the wait and went by fast when I was here.  This is by far a lot better than Starbucks any day!
author: Iver N.

description:
Super long lines usually give a sign of something worth looking into.

Got a standard coffee, put some milk in it - lo and behold it was amazing. I'm not usually someone who can tell the difference between this bean and that bean but this was a little different.

It tasted...well...a good different is the best I can put it. Let's just say it was enough for me to buy a bag of beans to take home and make on my own. My first cup was also pretty good.

For the price, it may not be something I do on a regular basis, but I'll be sure to have a bag of beans fresh and ready to make at home at all times.
author: Julia P.

description:
Went here on a Friday visit from the East Coast. What a nice business! The line was pretty long and they have a nondescript set-up so I figured that was two good signs. 

I ordered a Cafe Latte which was great. Their artistry at the top of the cup reminded me of my trip to Seattle. 

Their drinks are the perfect compliment to Acme Bread and cheese from Cowgirl Creamery. 

One last note: I noticed a lot of people eating their waffles. I'm assuming they are pretty good but I skipped them for the previously mentioned bread and cheese.
author: Tom M.

description:
I've heard plenty of people love BB Coffee and hate on them as well for being overrated or hyped up too much.  I got there a half hour before meeting up with my group, and since I already ate lunch, I figured that 30 minutes should get me a shot at trying some Blue Bottle Coffee.  Waiting in line inside wasn't too bad although the sun shining down from the skylights above made it pretty damn hot.  I felt like I was under a heat lamp that whole time...

By the time I got to the front, i ordered an iced coffee...only one size.  That does keep things simple...I guess if I needed more, I should order two of them.  Anyways, they cranked my iced coffee out in minutes.  I didn't specify whether I wanted milk or sweetened or anything, it just showed up on the counter in a cup.  Already feeling parched, I took a sip and I finally got it.  This iced coffee was very balanced in terms of sweetness, creaminess, and coffee flavor.  For the first time in a while, I got their interpretation of an iced coffee drink, instead of me dictating what I wanted.  

I'd definitely come back to get another iced coffee if the line was shorter and probably would go to the outdoors kiosk instead of the indoors one.
author: Ben H L.

description:
The bonuses of this location in addition to the well-known dripped coffee, great latte with wonderful foam art most detailed leaves, new orleans iced coffee:

1. pastries, baked goods, some heavy duty waffle quarters
2. Japanese artisan manual coffee makers - beautiful glass work to admire
3. other odd novelty merchandizes of Blue Bottle, coloring book? tote? and hoodies? fun stuff
4. there was just a small three feet long counter, but now BB added a stand alone counter place off to the side, and opened the back also as windows for order. Italian counter at coffee shops are used for? Answer: mingling, meeting strangers, chat and laugh together. Excellent. It just keeps getting better.
author: Dilys S.

description:
I love love coffee but I never was able to try legit coffee before so I thought that there wasn't a place that could be better than starbucks....

oh how naive i was!! 
I really wanted to try the dripped coffee but the weather was too hot to get a hot drink. So i decided to get the Cafe Latte and it was so good!

Totally recommended. I wish there were more blue bottle cafe here where I live...

Line gets long but that should be obvious. It's just that good.
author: Eunice K.

description:
Complete fail on my part...

I was looking around for some sugar to sweeten my New Orleans iced coffee a bit... They had the pure sugar but I did not know that liquidy thing was liquid sugar... My bf and I were looking at people putting it in their coffees and I thought it was some weird oil or some way of drinking coffee at blue bottle coffee co.....

We ended up going to Phil's to get some sugar instead....Barely no line since we made it right before the rush...

Compostable cups... I don't think was a good idea.. It kept on spilling and leaking through!!!!!!!!!!!!  The way you drink you coffee tops are so weird and does not fit with your mouth/lips as my bf pointed out........

Maybe I should try the place out again but for now....complete fail on expecting a delicious coffee cup that afternoon at ferry building.
author: Kathy D.

description:
It's two stars and not one or half a star more! I love coffee, I need coffee, but I do not need to wait in a ridiculous line to get it. If there are more than five people in line it isn't worth the wait. I'm Vietnamese and think my local pho place can make just as good or better slow drip coffee and guess what? It doesn't cost an arm and a leg and half a day to get it. 

Give San Francisco something "unique" (if you can call coffee unique) and exclusivity to SF and just wait for the reviews to pour in with five stars. Yea, I love sf, but sometimes they get too hyped up over nothing.
author: Minnow N.

description: The drip is all i need! Their coffee is that good that I don't need the extra frills! The only downside i have for them is the long wait. I understand they make each cup upon order, but they seem short staffed. The cashier was making the coffee as he was also tending to the line. Maybe another staffer back there would help move the line along?
author: Pauline T.

description:
Not being from San Francisco I hadn't heard of Blue Bottle Coffee. But my financee had, and when we spent the afternoon together in the city he suggested we make this our first stop. I looked it up on yelp to get directions, and was surprised to find there were several locations. We settled on this location figuring it would be a good spot to walk around, and when we arrived at around 2:30 PM I was surprised to find a decently long line. But we're here, and a line is usually a sign that a place is good right? 

We waited about 10-15 minutes, and knew we were there for the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee, so didn't need to look at the menu too much. From what I gathered, it has the standard espresso drinks and their drip coffee is individually prepared, which seems pretty cool. We decided to share the coffee (that was a mistake) and when I received the iced coffee I was a tad bit disappointed that for almost $4 I barely got 12 oz. However, my concerns completely faded once I tried the iced coffee. Wow. Completely rich and delicious, full flavored without being bitter, and sweet without actually being sugary ( I  never put sugar in my coffee). Having worked at an independent coffee shop in Santa Barbara for 2 years I truly appreciate a good iced coffee. This was by far the best I've ever had. Now I just need to figure out how to have this again without having to travel 7 hours...

Definitely worth a stop if you're in the area!!
author: Kaelee E.

description: I had their Belgian waffle (made fresh $3) bookmarked but I couldn't pass up the New Orleans iced coffee ($3.75) while I was there. The Belgian waffle was good but not as sweet as I like. I actually prefer the waffles from the Waffle Mania truck. The New Orleans iced coffee was perfect - at least for me. I can't drink coffee black because it's just too bitter for me - I need some sugar. The New Orleans iced coffee is mellow enough that I don't need to add anything but it's still not sweet. Not sure if this would appeal to normal coffee drinkers but hubby can take it so it's a good compromise for coffee to share.
author: Jean K.

description:
I don't even like coffee. I prefer tea any day. But after having Blue Bottle I'm starting to think that maybe I just don't like BAD coffee (insert reference to a certain coffee chain that begins with Star and ends in Bucks).

Came here during one of the Ferry Building's busiest times (it was a Saturday during farmers market), and noticed a bit of a line. We thought it didn't look to bad and decided to wait it out. Half an hour later? Still in line. This coffee better be good.

And it was! 

The New Orleans style iced coffee is delicious! I had low expectations going into it, seeing as I never took to coffee to begin with, but I couldn't get enough of this one. It's not overly sweet, nor is it overly bitter. Just right. Strong, too. I'd probably be wired for a few hours if I drank the whole thing myself. 

The price is decent too, at under $4 a drink.

The wait was long, but that's because they make each coffee cup to order. So I'm not overly upset. I just won't be coming back at peak times. 

I'm still not completely converted to being a coffee drinker, but I'll make an exception every once in awhile for Blue Bottle.
author: Sally T.

description:
"Blue Booth (Song for the West Side)."
(To the tune of "Blue Moon Revisited (Song for Elvis)" by the Cowboy Junkies, the Trinity Session, and dedicated to the great baristas who work the Embarcadero).

I only want to say
That if there is a way,
I want my Blue Bottle back here with me
'Cause it's my true love,
My new only one, can't you see?

And on that fateful day,
I ordered my first one straight away.
A coffee so fine came into my arms
I drank it too quickly to keep it from harm.

You see, I was afraid
To wait in the long lines of day.
So I came bright and early one Saturday morn
And then it was over, and now I am torn.

Blue Booth, you saw me standing alone
Without caffeine in my heart
Without a cup of my own.
Blue Booth, you knew just what I was there for
You heard me saying a prayer for
Some java I really could care for.

I only want to say
That if there is a way
I want my Blue Bottle back here with me
'Cause it's my true love
My new only one, can't you see?
author: Bradley N.

description: Came to SF for a culinary expo and to visit friends, so I finally had my first Blue Bottle experience at the Ferry Building, right before hopping on the ferry.  Got the drip of the day and it was very smooth.  I didn't get the New Orleans Style iced coffee (touted as "liquid crack" by friends), as it was a bit cold, but I'll be back.  I posted a Vine of me getting my first cup (Kathy_Writer).  The big deal about this coffee brand is they're about being fresh: they roast their beans and it's out the door and to customers within 48 hours.  You can also order their coffee online, but the experience of getting your Blue Bottle in SF is second to none.
author: Kathy N.

description: A favorite gem in the area of mine. Lines are long, but the service is kind and thoughtful with my ingredients. I prefer the soy latte,  New Orleans iced coffee and local Hayes Valley blend.
author: Nina V.

description:
Alright Blue Bottle Barista, skip the attitude.

While the coffee was deliciously strong without being overly acidic or smokey, I just did not appreciate the attitude of the cashier and barista.  I am no blue bottle employee but as a lactose intolerant first generation  Italian raised on Cafe Trieste cappuccino and former barista at a chain who shall not be named, I have had ample opportunity to figure out how I like my coffee.  

So when I order a drip coffee topped off with a tad of steamed milk, I know what I want.  No, I do not want a cafe au lait.  And I don't want to have to explain that steamed milk should contain an equal amount of foam and milk either.  I want a strong cup of coffee with a big spoonful of steamed milk on top.  I should not end up with a cup of coffee with warm milk added.  I can do that at home in my microwave.  And when I tell you that what you gave me is not what I want, don't shrug me off.  Fix it.
author: Nicole R.

description:
I tried to get a cup of coffee here but the staff was so clueless and inefficient it took forever to just place an order.
If they KNOW that it takes them a few minutes to brew drip coffee, then they should shout out to the customers in line -- "can I start a drip coffee for anybody?" Jesus.
Instead the drip coffee girl just stood there like a mannequin. I love Blue Bottle, but never again.
author: Lisa T.

description: Wonderful coffee. I had a hot latte and my husband got the New Orleans which was a cold drip. Both were excellent!
author: Donna B.

description:
I hate to say this in fear of incurring the wrath of all of the coffee lovers in SF, but I was kinda underwhelmed by Blue Bottle... Maybe it was all the hype that just created these hugely inflated and unrealistic expectations, but I was disappointed.

My first time there, I tried the Caffe Mocha with Tcho Chocolate. That was about half a year ago, but what I remember is that the flavors seemed unbalanced... The chocolate flavor didn't seem to match well with the coffee, and I just didn't feel like it tasted good... And with that as the only requirement I have for coffee, I was pretty surprised.

My second time there about a month ago, I tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee. This was markedly better, so I would definitely recommend this one, but again, I wasn't all that impressed or amazed. 

I can see that Blue Bottle is special in that I'm not sure drinks like New Orleans Iced Coffee or Caffe Mocha with Tcho Chocolate are really that accessible in the city... (Most other coffee shops I've been to in the city don't seem to have specialty drinks as their focus, whereas Blue Bottle seems to have that kind of reputation. I'm using passive language because I'm really not a coffee connoisseur; I've just been to a few places in the Mission and I hear things here and there.) 

But now that I've started drinking black coffee, espresso, etc, I'm hoping to go back and figure out why people hold Blue Bottle in high esteem. So, until next time...
author: Emily H.

description:
Blue bottle is 1-2 notches above starbucks in ALL of their drinks. Sadly the same goes for the price. 

They are drip coffee (one cup at a time) so expect to wait a little to alot longer to get coffee. Since they've gone semi-mainstream the wait at peak times is longer than your 10 min break so don't even try it. 

p.s. Like most coffee shops the workers are as nice as their tip jars are full. 

another good comparison. 
Blue bottle = Apple
Starbucks = Microsoft
author: Norris T.

description: Fantastic coffee. Waffle blew me away. Malted yeast dough and beet sugar crystallized glaze. I could eat these every day!!! Must stop when in San Francisco
author: Jennifer B.

description:
In the wise words of Black Rob....LIKE WHOA. For a while Philz had the number one spot on my coffee list, but Blue Bottle is a close contender. The quality is rich. It has a crisp, clean, boldness on your taste buds. The line was long, but I would wait for this quality in a line that was three times as long. 
On a rare warm day in SF, I recommend the affogato. They serve it with Humphrey Slocombe's vanilla ice cream. After having this quality, you would spit on java mocha chip- plutthhhh! The espresso is like a kick in the mouth. The ice cream acts like your boyfriend/girlfriend taking care of you after you get your @ss kicked. Then at the end of the bowl you are sad that it's the end of your journey and confused because your brain registers that you just ate a smooth, milky caramel and not that orgasmic affogato.
author: Anna D.

description:
I guess consider my review bias, as I am not a coffee whore, and drink "fake coffee" such as Starbucks with complete satisfaction.

The wait was around 30 minutes, so the hype was definitely there, but I am just not  quite sure the taste was. I ordered the latte and wasn't at all impressed. It was just a little too sour for my liking compared to other fancy coffee shops. 

Note: If you are waiting for blue bottle inside the Ferry Building, there are actually two lines, and each line offers a different selection of coffee, so be sure to ask which is which before waiting 30 minutes!
author: Luby H.

description:
I'm so jealous of san franciscians! you guys get blue bottle coffee and we get starbucks...ugh! 

I was visiting from Dallas, Tx last week. Walked around the ferry building and found this lovely coffee shop. The line was longer than anywhere else inside the ferry building so I knew it must be good. It was breakfast time so I got a waffle and a latte. The waffle was fluffy and coated with sugar cinnamon goodness. It was big and delightful! The latte was over this world good! I get sick from starbucks coffee every now and then because of the type of milk they use. Blue bottle uses organic milk and it didnt make my stomach hurt at all. 

I loved every little sip of that latte! can you guys please open one up in Dallas? You'll do great in highland park area of Dallas. We need something else besides starbucks...bleh
author: Cat N.

description:
After lunch at Delica in the Ferry Building (http://www.yelp.com/biz/delica-san-francisco#hrid:F-8g7du5VnW7BVmyDo6J5A), my friend, who recently got into gourmet coffee, suggested we have a coffee at Blue Bottle.

"I've never been to Blue Bottle," I said.
"Come with me. This is coffee you have to experience," he said.

His boss had introduced him to this place, and as we approached, and I saw the two lines of people waiting, I marveled that this must be pretty awesome coffee.

While we waited (in the shorter line to the left, I might add) I really wanted the power of an affogato, but without the ice cream. The pretty and friendly female barista with dreads and tattoos suggested I try the gibralter.

Three little words: TRY THE GIBRALTAR. It's espresso heaven in a glass.

Not on their menu, the gibraltar originated in SF with Blue Bottle owner James Freeman while he was testing cappuccinos at his Hayes Valley location in 2005. His roasting partner, Steve Ford, suggested they put it in a gibraltar glass, and hence, the drink was born.

It's 4.5 ounces of a cortado or double shot of espresso with a bit of steamed milk, the size of a cappuccino in Italy, without the milk drowning out the deliciously intense Blue Bottle Coffee. 

It's like a shot glass of espresso, which is fun to down after a night of drinking shots of alcohol at a bar ; - )

What really impressed me was the flavor of the coffee (I had previously thought that only Peets was strong enough for me. Wrong!) and the patience with which the barista made the drink, despite the long line behind us. Love the little "heart" detail they finish it with.

I cannot wait until they bring Blue Bottle to the 'burbs!
author: Diana V.

description:
First and foremost, I love coffee and coffee shops the world over. I had my first Blue Bottle coffee experience and came away with split opinions. 

On the plus side: 
-Freshly pulled espresso from La Marzocco 
-Organic milks, including organic soy readily available
-The cashier mentioned that if the New Orleans iced coffee wasn't our style that we could have something else
-Lovely bar seating behind La Marzocco where people watching ensued, unfortunately leading to some of the following...

Areas of improvement for Blue Bottle:
-The posted menu is pretty simple though partially blocked by food offerings, making for a challenging menu perusal while waiting (too long) in line. 
-The wait - get ready for it. Sluggish employees meandering in retrieval of customer orders. 12 people in line; one constant barista pulling shots, sweating under the unusual 75 degree SF day (cheers to you man, thanks for working with a sense of urgency), one downright slacker of a cashier/brewed coffee preparer (with hand on hip, sipping iced espresso, literally watching coffee drip, painful to be in line) with several other employees wandering around, either not interested in serving the customers in line or too busy to be bothered.  


Blue Bottle has a reputation for a unique coffee experience and the concept is pretty great. Unfortunately, the overall feeling could best be described as aloof bordering on snobbish. The product is first class, the service mostly pretentious with an overall minimalist, coffee purist environment. I watched the cashier rebuff a customer for asking for their espresso on ice (again, 75 degrees in the city here and this appears to be exactly what YOU are sipping on!) why is this hard? Oh wait, it's not. I'd be willing to try Blue Bottle again but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Jen Y.

description:
The drip coffee is absolutely the best in San Francisco (and maybe all of California). Each cup is individually brewed and prepared.

I like to start my mornings here with one of their freshly made waffles which has a hint of caramel. It's sweet enough that you don't need any syrup and makes the perfect companion to your coffee.
author: Victor W.

description:
I'm not quite sure how to write this review, because part of me wants to write a super positive review since I had been looking forward to trying Blue Bottle forever and I definitely support local, yet another part of me wasn't that impressed (because of my recent foreign coffee contamination). 

I have to explain that I'm REALLY biased with coffee lately, since in the last 8 months I have been to two coffee havens -- Costa Rica and Italy. There's no way anything is ever going to top coffee from countries such as those.

Having said that, Blue Bottle coffee is great for San Francisco! I rarely find genuinely flavorful local coffee here, and it definitely was great compared to its competitors and the generic chains that the bulk of the population frequents. Blue Bottle coffee was definitely rich, something you don't find in the watered down variety that Starbucks serves.

I do have to say that this could very quickly become by drug of choice should I happen to live in San Francisco.

P.S. The Ferry Building location will be a zoo on weekends. Stand in the long line. It's worth it.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Drip brewed one cup at a time.  Only deficiency is the long wait.
Many regard Blue Bottle as the best coffee in the city.
author: Jeff C.

description: There are actually something like five of these at the ferry building on farmers market days, and every one of them is always busy. On a warm day, I really like the "New Orleans Style Iced Coffee," it's pretty much the perfect blend of coffee, spices, and cream. On a cold day, their lattes and cappuccinos are amazing (who are we kidding, they're always amazing). Ditch the other coffee places that are spread around the ferry building and find one of these, it's worth the wait!
author: Brian S.

description:
I've always known that SF is great for coffee and that it can even rival Seattle, so this time around, I decided to check out Blue Bottle.

I somehow made it to this location and they had everything set up on the outside.  After waiting in line for about 20 minutes, we got a New Orleans Iced Coffee and a latte.  The iced coffee was smooth and with a little bit of sugar.  It's already pre-mixed according to the house coffee of that day but they add the perfect amount of sugar to take a little bit of the bitterness.  As for the latte, of course the barista had good skills with the latte art and man the drink was smooooth.

I definitely see why people hype about Blue Bottle.  They really do take coffee seriously.  Just looking at the beans they have for sale makes me realize just how much of a coffee n00b I really am.  

Oh and I really might be addicted to single drip.  Thanks Blue Bottle.
author: Duke C.

description: This place was the first coffee shop I went in the U.S. I went to this place about three years ago...I didn't know anything about the U.S., even didn't speak English well (still not good though). Now it's is nostalgic flavor to me. I need to go back here soon.
author: Kaori M.

description:
If you want some amazing coffee and are in or around the Ferry Building, you MUST try some Blue Bottle Coffee! Wow..just wow..their espresso beans are magical. I just got a plain latte and it was delicious without any syrups..and normally I'm a vanilla latte type of gal, but no, not here...it's amazing just on its own. MmMmm! 

Just try it out, the inner caffeine fiend in you will be grateful :)
author: Akvile D.

description:
A "latte" people seem to love this place as evidenced by the longest line I've seen for coffee.

The latte had pretty latte art on top and if you're wondering where the sugar is, it is in the olive oil looking bottle (I think they said it was sugar and water?). The latte tasted thick and maybe the quality was better than other coffee shops, but taste wise, I wasn't impressed.
author: Emily C.

description:
First, I should caveat my review with the fact that I'm perfectly happy with Keurig-brewed coffee or Starbucks for the occasional white chocolate mocha. However, if you really like espresso and don't mind the line, you'll probably enjoy Blue Bottle more than I did.

After reading about Blue Bottle in a ton of food/exercise blogs, I figured it was a must-do while in San Francisco. I knew the line would be long, but I was hoping it was worth it...not really (at least to me). Maybe I'm not a coffee connoisseur.

To be fair, I think I ordered the wrong thing. I got cappuccino when I probably should've tried drip coffee. I just wasn't that impressed with the cappuccino - didn't seem worth the line to me. The prices weren't bad, but there also weren't size options and I could've used more coffee (maybe that's why I seem grumpy?)

My boyfriend's hot chocolate was good - definitely very chocolate-y!
author: Jess G.

description:
I love Blue Bottle!

This place is always, always packed. Expect a line, whether it be long or short. 

They have plenty of of coffee and awesome coffee making gadgets that I definitely do not know how to use for sale here.

Coffee is always on spot, and I've tried multiple drinks. 

The Ferry Building location is like the cherry on top. Take your drink and walk outside on a sunny day. Perfect.
author: Elaine H.

description: OMG, order the waffle!  thank me later.
author: Amy W.

description: Dark, rich, flavorful...Those are all adjectives that pop into my head when I think of the decadent cup of coffee that I purchased at the Blue Bottle Coffee Co. outpost in the Ferry Building Marketplace.  Though the line was lengthy, my caffeine needs were just as persistent.  I recalled positive reviews of the brand and hopped online to join my fellow coffee fanatics.  After one sigh-inducing sip, I understood why this brewer had come to be known as "cultish".  Blue Bottle Coffee Co. provided quite possibly the most substantial and memorable coffee experience of my life.  Whether you have yet to join the ranks of us caffeine heads or you are in need of an upgrade to your usual blend, I highly recommend a taste of luscious coffee goodness from the Blue Bottle Coffee Co.
author: Alison C.

description:
Between Four Barrel, Philz, and Ritual, I have to say, Blue Bottle just does it for me.

They're consistently good and make exceptionally tasty soy lattes EVERY TIME.

Though this location is a bit touristy and always has an annoyingly long line, it's well worth it for some of their artfully brewed coffee.
author: Adena B.

description: I always drink black drip coffee and this place pass my litmus test. Definitely better than Starbucks drip if you like black coffee. Although I don't like the line and wait. For a cup of coffee the service should be faster. I recommend Blue Bottle if you like coffee.
author: Evan C.

description: BB --  best coffee I think I have ever had.  Thankfully they are in NYC now!
author: Alexandra C.

description: When in Rome one must drink as the Romans do! What a treat to finally have blue bottle at its very birth locale.  I think I've been to most everyone of their stores & kiosks!
author: Sean S.

description:
Real coffee, real rich, and real strong. 
The line wasn't extremely long when we were there. We saw someone holding a shot glass of coffee and was curious to know what that was. It looked like a miniature latte. The man told us it was a Gibraltar. The staff was happy to explain exactly what that was and how great the balance of tastes were. So of course we had to order it. The way I would describe it would be that it's like a cross between a cappuccino and a strong latte. There's no sugar added so it allows you to really appreciate the coffee for what it is. And if you don't like the bitterness you will need to add sugar. 

They also have a "secret window menu" and the bakery items are only served till 4:30pm, I believe. I don't really know if this is really a secret but you can only see the menu if your up at the cash register. 

Wasn't anything too outstanding to me but a real coffee connoisseur may think otherwise. Turns out the Gibraltar is #28 on the 7x7 Top 100 List. Yay $2.75 and another one crossed off!
author: Karen C.

description:
My favorite coffee shop in the Bay when I am visiting. 

I have tried all the hype places... Ritual, Four Barrel, etc. and always come back to Blue Bottle. I prefer to stand on the line on the side and get a Single Origin Capp.

Waffles are a must get as well!
author: Andy L.

description:
So sorry I bothered you at work.  Don't worry, I won't do it again.
Only bad coffee/food experience I've ever had in SF.
author: Kate K.

description:
More of an espresso guy but was told to try their infamous New Orleans-style iced coffee.  I know nothing about what makes it New Orleans style but as it was being poured I knew it was going to be good because it was also pretty dang hot outside.  It was going to be great and the experience mind-blowing....until they poured the creamer in without asking me if I wanted it.  When I get iced coffee, I usually just put just enough half and half in to tone down the acidity and a bit of simple syrup to complement the coffee flavor.  I always taste the iced coffee black before adding it.  Alas, the coffee was a bit too sweet for me although it was still good.  

I also ordered a bag of their Giant Steps coffee as suggested by the barista.  Despite the line, the barista was kind enough to ask me what my preferences were before I bought a bag.  I tried some today in my trusty coffeemaker and it's really delicious.  Highly recommend.  

It's possible this place could become a 5 star for me since their coffee product is quality but I would have to try their espresso and I don't think this place will have too many opportunities for me to upgrade to 5 star since the lines are long and I only visit SF occasionally.
author: Matthew K.

description: Writing 100 Yelp reviews this year has been an at times obsessive pursuit, so it seems appropriate for my 100th review to be for a coffee stand with such an obsessive following.  I do completely appreciate the single-brewed drip coffee, and there wasn't even a hint of bitterness in my cup ... but waiting in line for 45+ minutes?  It was okay since I was doing the touristy thing with a friend and spent the time catching-up, but there's no way I would put up with it on a daily basis especially when there is a Peet's on the other side of the Ferry Building.  Worth a try if you have plenty of time, or feel the need to join the hipster coffee cult.
author: Susan Y.

description:
I'm no coffee connossieur but all I can tell you is to prepare for the 20-30 minute wait for your coffee.  Quality definitely takes time and you can tell there's a lot of love in your drink.  They drip each individual coffee!!!  One side of you says that is awesome and the other side says wasteful when you look at the buckets of coffee filters & beans.

Knowing that I did not want just a shot of something (espresso, macchiato, etc.), I got the Caffe Mocha.  If you are normally a fan of super sweet coffee drinks they serve at most chain coffee shops, then you might not like this.  It has a slightly bitter, very aromatic, and super thick taste to it.  My only grips were that it was served almost lukewarm and about 1/4 the cup (if not more) contained foam.

Of course you can't resist the pretty designs they make on top of your drink.  I got a heart. 

Another plus? Free macaroons from Miette Patisserie!!  They had two big box fulls of vanilla parisian.  A lot of non-Blue Bottle customers were grabbing them as they walked by but still, none of the employees said anything.  But hey can you blame them when these little delights cost $1.50 each at the bakery.
author: Shannon L.

description: I love Blue Bottle, but the service I got yesterday is inexcusable. I waited at the counter for 10 minutes without any acknowledgement or greeting from the staff. There were two workers socializing with each other, and making obvious attempts to avoid eye contact with me as I stood there, staring at them. I then spoke up and asked if I was going to be helped, or acknowledged, or receive any customer service what-so-ever. Finally the man who was standing behind the counter the whole time asked me "What can I get for you?" He was obviously not in the middle of anything, and simply did not want to service me. His name was AJ, and when I said that I am not used to this low level of service from Blue Bottle, he did not apologize throughout the entire ordeal. He provided me with flat-affected service, took my money, and sent me off.
author: An I.

description:
4 months of hype, and what do I have to show for it?

"Damn, thats good coffee!" was all I said after my first sip. 

Because damn. Thats good coffee.
author: Emily D.

description:
Best coffee in town, yeah yeah you know.

Take a sip, start hallucinating, A Beautiful Mind, Russell Crowe.
Make a bald man grow, a ginger afro. Turn that frown to a smile, Robert Dinero. May even slow Aunt Flow. Substantial Bowel movement, time to go numero dos! Don't say, I didn't tell you so. Maybe a waffle for a buck fiddy, "Waffle Machine still broken?" Oh hells no! "It been 3 months ho!"

Long lines for the grind, jog down a few feet to Plant cafe, they serve the same, dumbo! One way or another, Can't beat Blue bottle's cup a Joe.

shhh..

Cut the wait time in half, 9am, use the secret Door.
author: Sani S.

description:
Love love filter drip coffee.. I am such an impatient person, but due to my insane caffeine addiction, I will wait for the precious drop after drop of the goodness that filter drip coffee offers.  I will wait for coffee..  

I am saddened but at the same time am relieved for my bank account there isn't a Blue Bottle near my work or home, because I'd go daily...

Honestly, I love Philz more, but Blue Bottle is great too..

The aroma of roasted coffee is just soo...  delicious..
The filter drip coffee renders the beans sweet and smooth, without the bitterness or the aftertaste of roasted coffee beans..

Honestly.. good coffee makes me soo happy :)
author: Jen K.

description: I'm currently obsessed with blue bottle coffee. It's smooth and light in tannins which makes it easy for a non coffee drinker to enjoy and creates a fan for life of the people that regularly consume a daily cup of joe.
author: Oulie T.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee: A haiku

I ordered the drip.
Crowded at lunch, thus I wait.
One sip: I'm in love.
author: Mary C.

description:
I buy coffee beans at Philz and this is where I come to get espresso beans. They are, in my opinion, the best espresso beans in San Francisco.

The only stressful element while getting coffee beans is that Blue Bottle coffee has about 10 blends and they're not categorized. The line is always long and I don't like taking other customers' time by asking questions while trying to choose the ones I'm going to purchase. Yes, they're listed on their website but my cell phone reception is bad at the ferry building and I'm unable to look them up.
author: Elma C.

description: I'm not quite sure what happened here. I came by the Ferry Building about 30 minutes early so I could grab some lunch on the go before hopping on the Amtrak bus. I stopped by Blue Bottle to grab a coffee. Ended up ordering a cafe latte. I waited patiently in line and then again for my drink to be made. The barista topped off my drink with some latte art swan. I really wanted to like Blue Bottle because everybody raves about this place but the milk in my latte overpowered the drink. I couldn't taste any coffee. Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing? I'm going to have to give this place another try before I make up my mind.
author: Sarah L.

description:
In all honesty, Yelp is getting out of control. As much as I love to write Yelp reviews for the purpose of knowing where I have been, it is pretty outrageous that I "have" to review the same place twice... once for its distribution (Cowgirl Creamery, for example) and another for its "tasting location" (Cowgirl Creamery Sidekick, as assumed). They are normally located in the EXACT SAME SPOT.

Alas, I love Yelping, so I will continue to follow in the footsteps as others.

Blue Bottle Coffee Stand is awesome. They do $2.75 pour-overs, which they nonchalantly advertise as "individually prepared drip coffee." That is truly commendable. In many a city I have partaken in hand-poured caffeinated beverages at, they really push that whole "pour over" culture. Way to go, Blue Bottle. For that, you receive 5 stars.

My cup o' joe was great. Bold with a touch of tartness. Well... there is no need to describe the characteristics, much less the nuances, as I am certain that they rotate their specific "bean o' the day" regularly.

Anyway... if you are going to Blue Bottle Coffee, you might as well go to Blue Bottle Coffee Stand to taste the other offerings of the institution from which you are purchasing your items for or to help produce coffee drinking. Oh wait, they are in the EXACT SAME LOCATION. Wow; GPS would freak.
author: Solomon W.

description:
Blue Bottle makes my favorite soy latte. Ever! The flavor is so exactly pristine, it's actually a shame to put sugar in their coffee. The use of high quality soy milk, and attention to details in every step from the temperature of the water, milk, to the grind and press of the beans is evident in the end product. 

Go during the week when it's a reasonable wait, and you will truly enjoy how well this coffee is made. Expect looooooong lines and waits on the weekends, even given the two coffee counters that take advantage of the corner location.
author: Ting S.

description:
Vibe: More chill and relaxed than the location inside.

Coffee: It's the same-old, amazing Blue Bottle coffee and talented baristas.

Service: The folks at the stand at more chill, relaxed and friendly than those inside due, most likely, to being outside and not jam-packed. Oh, an you'll wait half as long for your latte outside than you will inside. Winning!

Value: Same price as inside, but faster and more convenient (check out the food trucks while you wait). Awesomeness!
author: Luke B.

description:
Finding really good, really wonderful coffee is like finding your eternal soulmate. I've had the good fortune to at least discovering the former.

Rich, robust, smooth and aromatic. This coffee will change your life. Or not. But it definitely makes an impression. It will make your day and bring you to that relaxed, don't-bother-me-I'm-drinking-amazing-coffee state of being. 

My sister's gotten a half pound of one of their blends and it was really good. You can't go wrong -- Iced. Hot. Mocha. They're all good.
author: Amber M.

description:
I'm giving Blue Bottle 5 stars for their Lattes and Cappuccinos.  Overall, you can't really go wrong with anything you order here--however, like a lot of great places, there are the "must haves" that put this place on the map.  At Blue Bottle, you must try the Latte or Cappuccino.

The way they make the Latte and Cappuccino at Blue Bottle is like no other.  You can tell this is the real deal by incorporation of milk foam with the espresso (not just a light foam floating on the top, which is what you get at Starbucks).  There is a nice ring of the rich espresso lining the thick milk foam which usually has a nice design of some sort (e.g., hearts, leaves, etc).
