TIP 1: As most coffee connoisseurs will tell you, you should really get your latte/cap with Whole Milk for the best cup.
TIP 2: Get your latte/cap for sit down. It's best to enjoy this for sitting-in, without the to-go lid (as the foam gets stuck to the top of the lid).

If I were to rate Blue Bottle for their drip coffee, I'd have to lower my rating to a 4.  This is primarily for the reason that I prefer Philz drip over Blue Bottle and sometimes the drip coffee at Blue Bottle can be inconsistent depending on who is making it (sometimes it's a bit lighter than other times). Nonetheless, still a good cup of joe.
author: Miyuki I.

description: Last time I visited this spot I found out about the "secret" window on the side of the stand.  This window is often passed by so I think the regulars know that it is faster in this line (in theory).  The coffee here is really good and smooth.  I think the only reason why I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars is that it's not a feasible place to get a "quick" coffee because every order takes on average 3 - 4 minutes...so if you run down from the embarcadaro with a few co-workers it will take about 15 minutes just to get your coffee!
author: Sara H.

description:
02.26.12

No trip to the Ferry Building is complete until you get a drip coffee from Blue Bottle.

There are TWO lines at this location.  I don't want to tell you which one is shorter/better because I want to wait less.
author: Jenny L.

description: Cappuccino: pretty good. Perhaps a bit burned. They also don't have Splenda. They only have "organic sugar". F dat!! I want some Splenda in my cappuccino. Shape up! I waited in this mutha f -in line! Don't burn my shit and get me some Splenda!
author: gary g.

description:
When I went earlier to ferry plaza farmers market I decided to go here first of course. I needed a boost to start my morning. My hubby had the Cappuccino which is always good and I had their cafe latte and I enjoyed it.
To make it short, good real coffee. Period!
author: Cryszilla G.

description:
I may get death threats for giving Blue Bottle two stars. 

I've always believed that the customer is always right. 

You know, I don't drink coffee. Never have. I came to Blue Bottle because EVERYONE raves about it. Given the yelp reviews and fanatical following that was obvious by the huge line I decided to take my mother there on her weekend in SF. 

To make a long story short I ordered a hot chocolate for myself and a latte for my mother. 

We waited about 15 minutes. I wasn't in a huge rush (I rarely am) but I got a little bothered when people who had ordered 5 and 10 minutes after me started getting their drinks before me. 

Now, I'm a logical person. I thought to myself: those must be drinks that are more difficult to make and therefore they are getting theirs first. 

Then I started to notice that people who ordered after me AND had the same drink were getting theirs first. 

I won't jump to conspiracy theories as to why this was. It just was. 

I approached the gentleman and politely asked if my drink was ready and mentioned that I had been waiting some time. I was told that I was next....you know, behind the guy who ordered way after me and ALSO ordered a  latte. 

When I finally got my drink I again politely said to the gentleman helping me if there was an ordering system they adhered to because I had been put behind several people who ordered after me with similar drinks. Taking me for a moron and ignoring the fact that I already said that people (not 1 or 2 or 3....like 6 because I counted) with the same drinks got theirs ahead of me. He was not apologetic and stuck to his story that there is an order. 

Thanks, guy. All I wanted was an apology for something that I had observed that seemed kinda wrong. In the future if a customer seems ticked I would suggest apologizing even if you don't mean it. 

I'd rather get a crappy non Michael Ricchiuti hot chocolate at Starbucks. At least they have figured out a way to get drinks to people in an order that makes sense.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Wow!

Had the New Orleans Styled Iced coffee on two separate visits during my short stay in SF.

To keep it short and simple...

Pros:
Staff
Taste
Vibe
Location
Price

Cons:
Waiting in line (A line that moves very quickly).
author: James H.

description:
Wholly crowded coffee stand Batman!

This place was insane on a Saturday afternoon.  Service was fast, but almost too fast, my coffee was not hot at all.  I like my coffee piping hot, so hot that I can't drink it and must sip it,  

As for flavor, my mocha was delicious, rich, chocolaty and creamy....yummmmm....

5 stars had my coffee been hot!

Next time, I will try the Mint Plaza location, that's where all the locals seem to go?
author: Heather K.

description:
Me: My star rating is based only on the quality of the coffee and how well it lives up to what it's trying to be.  I don't care about service if the coffee is good.

After hearing the hype and seeing massive lines for a few hours, we braved the line and my friend ordered a latte.  I had a few sips and it basically tasted like steamed milk.  Where was the coffee flavor?  

Overall: If I were you, I would get out of the line for blue bottle, walk 15 feet to the gelato place (Ciao Bella) right across the way, and get a scoop of their Turkish Coffee flavor along with a scoop of one of their sweet vanilla flavors.
author: Tom C.

description: Blue Bottle is a great coffee stop in the Ferry Building. The lines are LONG but they have several different spots you can wait and pick up a cup from. I don't usually drink drip coffee and now I'm thinking I should have tried it. I did order my usual non fat latte and one thing I am most appreciate for is they actually have "non fat" milk - as good as Four Barrel is, they only have Whole Milk and well... no one in their right mind has any business drinking Whole Milk. My latte was great and gave me a nice little buzz to kick off our day in San Fran as we strolled around the Ferry Building Marketplace.
author: Candace L.

description: Honestly, I don't understand the hype.  This just seems like a pretentious yuppie thing to me.  Every cup of coffee I have had from Blue Bottle tastes totally burned - it's bitter and burned tasting.  I have better things to do with my shopping time at any farmer's market than to stand in line for a cup of bitter, burned tasting drip coffee for 20 minutes.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Long lines usually mean a good thing. However, after standing for nearly 30 minutes, I couldn't stand it. It was like waiting in line for a Disneyland ride when all I wanted was to grab my coffee and go. When I finally got my mocha, I was pleased with the design, yet it was like any other mocha I've had. Yes it was less sweeter than the others I've had and that I liked, but it was nothing special. I believe it's all hype like the words swag and yolo.

Laugh out loud.
author: May D.

description:
Their latte's are a little bit of heaven.

I normally need to wait a few minutes for coffee drinks but the wait is well worth it. It is a treat when I go there, so I add the wait time for this experience. I have waited less time at other locations. I have had the drip, mocha and lattes. All super. I also try to buy a new blend of coffee for home every time I go. That way I can relive my experience at home. I enjoy my Starbucks for the consistency and quickness but when I have time and I am in the city, I love to have Blue Bottle.
author: Stephen B.

description: I had a tasty drip coffee. It was crowded, and people were in the line.  The aroma of the coffee was very nice.
author: Yaeko M.

description: WOW! I've never had anything like their New-Orleans Ice coffee before and it was good. It wasn't too bitter, not too sweet, and was a good deal. The drink went down smooth and compared to other times I've drinken coffee it didn't leave a coffee taste in my mouth and it didn't make my stomach feel like i was going to have an ulcer. It was a nice refreshing coffee drink I've ever had. Just be prepared to wait in line. They got pretty busy.
author: Arun M.

description:
I love going here after a run on Embarcadero or after a Giants game. Not only is it in a convenient place on Embarcadero, the views just outside on the pier is just perfect on a nice sunny day in SF. Ive been going here for a couple of years now and lately the people seem hit or miss--the coffee is still great. 

My favorite thing here is the Affogato. It is AWESOME when prepared right. BUT like said above, the people here are hit or miss these days. The last time I got it, the ice cream was all melted and it came out even more watery when the expresso was poured on it. It is suppose to have solid scoops of humphrey's ice cream and a shot of expresso on top--the ice cream should only minimally melt. Both the cashier who scooped the ice cream and the barista who poured on the expresso shot tried to play it off like it was suppose to be like that--that I did no appreciate and that is why I am giving this place the three stars that I did. 

But for those fans, the coffee itself hasn't seemed to change--just some of the personnel.
author: alfred c.

description: Best Coffee in San Francisco. I wish these were on every corner.
author: Justin S.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place! Numerous friends recommended it to me, so I was really expecting the best coffee I've ever had. I waited in line 30 minutes for a cappuccino, and when I finally took my first sip, it was room temperature (maybe slightly lukewarm). While I do appreciate the beautiful free pour latte art, I wish the barista spent a little more time foaming the milk! 

I am hoping to try Blue Bottle again next time I am in SF. I feel like the experience I had was probably not representative of their normal quality.
author: Kayla K.

description:
In general, I prefer beans from other coffee roasters in the area to Blue Bottle, who roasts beans on the darker side. However, their earthy Three African's blend is a reliable winner, and their baristas are always friendly and knowledgeable. I appreciate this stand in particular, because without caffeine, how can I be expected to take on the hefty task of choosing among fourteen varieties of heirloom organic carrots? 

A surprise hit for me is the New Orleans Iced Coffee. As a rule, either chicory root or sugar in my coffee is DEE-SGUSTING, but there's something special about the Blue Bottle take on this, because their version is nothing short of magical happiness elixir.
author: Monica S.

description:
Blue bottle coffee is amazing. They handle their coffee with care and it shows in the taste and look. If you're looking for good coffee, this is it.

TIP: There's a side window near the restrooms that they do orders from and that line is usually a lot shorter than the longer line at the main entrance.
author: Steven B.

description: Why is it that we are willing to wait on long lines for coffee?  Perhaps it's to support the local people and flavors.  I'm a fan of the afogoto with the humphry slocombe ice cream for dessert.  They've also got some creative cookies whether it's Tahitian vanilla, ginger molasses, or chocolate saffron.  Be prepared to stand and chat for awhile!
author: Jenny L.

description:
"its hard to be humble when youre the finest"

Renee has this shirt advetising the US Marines - and just like the usmc, blue bottle is the finest, and far from humble. Semper Coffee.
author: Oleg H.

description:
For those that really appreciate a great cup of coffee, Blue Bottle is simply the best.  I mean, the quality of their coffee is so far beyond the typical everyday coffee many are used too and content with.  There is a rich yet subtle complexity that invigorates the coffee tasting glands.

On a recent trip I discovered their Affogato.  I can comfortably say this was the best thing I've eaten in 2011.  Think thick, rich, velvety smooth double espresso shot topped over Humphrey Slocomb's vanilla ice-cream.  The bitter sweet caramel espresso harmonizes with the sweet ice-cream and produces a yin-yang mouthful experience that can't be matched anywhere anytime.  The espresso brings out the amazing sweetness of the ice-cream while the sweet ice-cream brings out the smoothest strongest espresso flavor of any coffee ever brewed.  The beautiful aroma of this combination literally produces Lost's "black smoke monster" which punch's the face of every Folger's coffee consumer in the world. 

The Affogato is the best kept secret of San Francisco.
author: Rhett S.

description:
Pros:
- Great coffee!!!

Cons:
- NO seating area
- Most of the baristas are cold and not helpful. This one girl who took my order was nice and smiled. Everyone else acted like they could care less who was there.
- Kinda confusing set up - two places where you could order, but I felt like I waited around cause I thought there was a line, when there wasn't, and the baristas didn't have the sense to tell me otherwise.
- Pastries options a little disappointing

If I'm at/near Ferry Plaza, Ill probably go back for a cup of coffee. But I wouldn't pick this place to meet up with friends as it's not a very friendly atmosphere/ambiance and there really is no place to sit.
author: Vaibhavi U.

description: I loved the New Orleans iced coffee - a touch of milk and sugar over cold brew. Fantastic.
author: Joel B.

description: Recently, I had a Cafe Au Lait and it was not good that I didn't even finish it.  What a bummer!  I'm not as excited about their coffee as I used to be now that it's readily available at a bunch of restaurants, cafes, and shopping centers.  Feels like they're starting to mass produce coffee and that's when the quality goes down.
author: Erica S.

description: Extremely busy but very speedy, which was appreciated.  Thoroughly enjoyed my TCHO Mocha... I forced myself to savor my mocha because it wasn't very hot and I could have finished it in 3 swigs.  It was cold and windy that day, so I needed all the caffeine and warmth I could find!
author: Scott P.

description:
I'm not a big "designer coffee" type of guy. 

Matter of fact, I'm the guy who refuses to order in Starbucks lingo, meaning, I say: "I'll have a small black coffee" instead of: "I'd like a venti, double tall, nonfat extra whip decaf americano with soy."

To me, that kind of lingo only causes me to shake my head side to side in my thoughts while I think: "you sound like an complete idiot" to myself.

Furthermore, I'd like to meet the person who came up with the title of "Barista", seriously, this person has got to go. You sir (or Ma'am) are the reason men wear skinny jeans, glasses with no lenses and wool caps in 90 degree weather. 

And now you've created a "hip, chic and swanky" title for yourself because you are insecure about your minimal paycheck.

And yes, I know it means Bartender in Italian and the history of the name. 

But you don't see people going around priding themselves as "Hamburger Flippers" and that's kinda like the same thing if you REALLY think about it.

Think about it, if a Barista is really a type of profession then damn man, I'd say about 95 percent of Americans qualify for this finely crafted and delicate skill, see ya later recession!! 

Anyway, getting to the point.......................................................

I ordered my typical "Small black coffee" here and, was corrected by the barista, wearing skinny jeans that it was "Fresh French Drip Recycled Green Filter Coffee"

***Sigh***



.............somebody get me rope so I can start tying a noose for myself.


In the meantime I'll savor this "small black coffee" that was made without "F*cking it up" as I like to refer to it as.
author: Patrick O.

description:
A little pricy but totally worth the money and the wait!
I will gladly switch my daily starbucks to the Blue Bottle if it was closer.
author: Dalu Q.

description:
Okay seriously, I don't think it should come as a surprise when I say, Blue Bottle Coffee has some of the best coffee I've ever tasted. Suffice to say though, that I am not a coffee snob. I don't know too much about coffee beans, or acidity or whatever else you're supposed to look for in coffee...

However, I do know that the Latte at Blue Bottle is one of the few where I actually prefer not to add any sweetener. I know some of the coffee purists out there will shun me for adding sweetener to any coffee but the truth is that most coffee for me tastes better with sugar. Not Blue Bottle. That espresso with a little bit of steamed milk just hits me in the right spot and it's not just 'cuz of the caffeine high. It really makes me happy. 

I would venture to say the only downside to Blue Bottle is the occasional ridiculous wait. You'd do best to look for those downtimes when the crowds aren't around. I suppose you could say, try to avoid Saturday mornings when the Farmer's Market is going on but sometimes...even then it is worth the wait.
author: Esther J.

description:
Blue bottle is the only coffee that I can stand to consume in the US.

Starbucks and Peets taste like horse pee to someone that grew up drinking coffee in India. 

That being said, the reason I gave this place 3 stars is because of the God awful service. Seriously, how long does it take to brew a cup of plain ol' coffee?
author: Ranjani S.

description:
This might be deemed the best coffee place in the area, and I can't really put my input about it as I'm not a coffee drinker. BUT I am going to write this review about customer service.

I just recently bought a 1/2 pound of coffee grinds as a gift. The cashier did not greet me, he did not ask how he can assist me, he just asked, "that's it?" That's a good question, if the conversation started with, "Hello, what can I get you?" I handed him the coffee, and the interaction was very straight forward. He placed his hand out, I handed him my credit card, and while I was just adjusting the coffee bag in a bag, he left the credit card on the table and walked away. I stood there for a good 4-5 minutes. He didn't acknowledge me afterward, I wasn't sure if I was waiting for a receipt or waiting to sign the receipt because I did say, "I need a bag, it's a gift." There was only one person behind me, it was NOT busy, because it's understandable if you blatantly blow me off bc you are busy. But he wasn't even making drinks for any people standing by, he wasn't completely done for that 5 minutes. Finally, I asked another employee, "Umm..do i need to sign anything from my credit card swipe." His response, "You're good." No "thank you" for my business.

I like good food/beverages, but what makes an establishment great, is the accommodation of good service.
author: Minette C.

description: This is a wonderful coffee spot.  There was a long line up.  I had the pour over into milk and the taste of the coffee was outstanding.  Smooth and not bitter.  I saw the owners of the business and told them they need to open one in Canada.  It is clear that there is some great attention to detail.  I overheard one of the workers training and precision was key!  I had the waffle and wish I could have had 4 more.  This place will not disappoint.
author: M F.

description:
After reading all the Blue Bottle reviews, I have had a hankering to make it  up to San Francisco to try it for myself. My big mistake was arriving at the Ferry Bldg. Farmers' Market after 10 on Saturday morning. In fairness, the nice lady taking our money did say that a drip would be at least 5 minutes (it was close) and a latte would take 20 (actually closer to 30), but after the long wait to get to SF, and another 20 for the best coffee in the world didn't seem like huge commitment.

The verdict: the drip my husband had was definitely wonderful. We ended up buying 2 half pounds of different coffees and are very much enjoying each of them. You could swear the Amaro Gayo Natural has been altered to have such a fruity flavor. Though not for everyone, I love this coffee.

The lattes are certainly pretty. Many of the pictures people have uploaded will attest to that. The drink has a large layer of soft, foamy steamed milk. The layer was actually too much for me. It seemed to overpower the espresso flavor. But, maybe by the time I got the coffee, I was weighing the time cost against the taste/specialness benefit. While I am happy to have finally tried Blue Bottle, next time there is a long wait I'll go for the drip and leave someone else to enjoy the artistic drinks.
author: MaryFran L.

description:
Some decent coffee that somehow got the cachet from hipsters that this is THE BEST coffee in the world.  Waited in line for this coffee for about 20 minutes only to find that it is just... OK.  Nothing spectacular.  I definitely wouldn't wait in line for this again.  Maybe possibly I'll try it again when the lines aren't that long, but I definitely won't be rushing back. 

Prices are a tad high, but what do you expect from hipster coffee? In San Francisco, the shit doesn't taste good unless you are paying at least $3.50 a cup.  That's why I tell them, gimme the most expensive shit!!! It makes the flavor more rich.. get it, more rich?!?! Corny...
author: Jason Y.

description:
Drip coffee and waffle....best way to start off your morning! Their New Orleans style coffee tastes like a vietnamese coffee, so if you're in the mood for a slightly stronger coffee, I'd recommend that. 

Enjoy a cup of coffee while walking around the farmers market on a nice, sunny Saturday morning. Great start to the weekend.
author: Vi L.

description:
I love coffee, especially great coffee like the coffee at Blue Bottle.  I'm also fairly cost conscious which is why I buy beans and grind them at home and make my own coffee.  Why do I get the feeling every time that I go here to buy beans that I'm doing something wrong?  

The service here could possibly be the worst I have ever experienced, and I'll give it to them, it's consistent, of the 8 or so times I've bought beans here, I have never once dealt with anyone even remotely friendly, anyone who valued the fact that I was spending my money here, or cognoscente of the idea that when I get to the register and have a bag of beans in my hand, that I would like to purchase said beans and be on my way.  Every time I get to the front of the line, I feel like the barista does everything they can to compete every task that they can possible do before taking my hard earned cash.  

You know what, I'm done with this place, I just can't deal with the most smug bunch of brats to ever be employed in one small location.  I'll get my beans somewhere else and I'll enjoy the fact that I won't feel annoyed every time I walk away with a bag of beans.

Peace out Blue Bottle, we've had good times and bad times, but in the end it's not me, it's you!
author: Jonathan U.

description:
This is one of the better gimmicks in a city prone to them. Good coffee, yes. But it's a bit like going to a concert in which your favorite singer spends a ton of time rambling on between songs, when all you really paid to hear was all of your favorite music. You want to love it, but in your head you keep thinking "Just sing, honey. Just sing!"

That's how I feel about Blue Bottle...
author: Opinions Are My Own, G.

description:
Gibraltar! I finally tried it after embarrasing myself and asking them 
Me: "hey do you guys have those coffee shots?"
Cashier: "yeah espresso?"
Me: "uh it starts with a g.... Gibra something"
Cashier: "gibraltar *smiles*"
Me:"lol yeah can I have that?"
Cashier:*laughs* "yeah?2.75"

And fellow yelpers thank you for your advice I loved it! It has a bitter,strong taste in the beginning but towards the end it had that sweet taste. I love coffee and so far this tops of my list!
Def. coming back to try a different kind of coffee :)
5 stars!!!
author: Anna P.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is like crack. 

-I wake up in the morning feeling like I can't live without it. 
-No other drug (coffee brand) gives me the same excitement and high. And once you've had a taste of the good stuff (Blue Bottle Coffee), I swear there is no going back.
-It's all I can think about at 2:30PM every workday (worst part of the day, might I add.)

Blue Bottle Coffee, I love you.
author: Jasmin W.

description:
Hook up an IV of the Blue Bottle Iced Coffee...I've never had a better iced coffee. I was told that it comes with some chicory and some other sweeteners, as it is a "New Orleans" style iced coffee. I also added soy milk (any milk will do) at the suggestion of the barista. Normally I don't put anything into my coffee, but apparently a little bit is necessary.

Upon writing this review, I have learned that there is a location in Brooklyn, NY...which I intend to visit and then never leave.
author: Evan H.

description:
Really.good.coffee.

Their mocha was one of the best I've ever tasted.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Stop by blue bottle for a cup of coffee and walk around the ferry building while sipping on a nice cup of hot coffee. 

My mom got their macchiato and really enjoyed it. It came in a little cute cup and they did a small coffee art design of a heart.

I got their drip coffee and really enjoyed mine. The coffee is good, but not as hot as I like my coffee to be.
author: Chris K.

description:
Ferry Bldg
Perfectly deadly café mocha with Tcho chocolate and soy
Friendly food service
author: Rosquete B.

description:
This is by far the most awesome coffee place I've ever been to, in the entire world :) Seriously - I vote this higher than cappuccinos in random little cafes in Paris or Italy, this place truly crushes your expectations about what coffee can be.

Ferry Building has 2 stands, at the front and on the side of the building, for some reason I always go to the side one, but they are basically equivalent. There is also a shop inside the Ferry Building now too, which rocks. My favourite is the side stand though.

I almost always get the same thing - cappuccino. It is creamy, smooth, beautifully balanced with milk and light froth on top, and a cute and well-presented "coffee art" image drawn in the top with milk. The baristas are true artists!

The New Orleans Iced Coffee is friggin' life-changing too. Be careful, once you have one, you'll be back every single week for another.

Drop whatever you are doing and go the Ferry Building on a Saturday from 8am-2pm, get a coffee here to start your day, and explore the fantastic farmer's market with the best coffee you'll ever have in your life. A+++.
author: Mike J.

description:
Cafe Affogato!  
It's a long line, a long wait, but it's soooo darn good.  One time it was served with Humphrey Slocombe bourbon and cornflake ice cream! Another time with something like Humphrey Slocumbe honey thyme!
author: Bill B.

description:
Found this place though some guide books for San Francisco. 
I love trying good coffee when I get a chance! 
The location is inside of the Ferry building, and there always seems to be a long time. While my friends and I were waiting in line, they have merchandise around the place. it's not an actual sit-down coffee place but more of a store front, you get your coffee and go. :) 

Got to the register after 20 minutes, I got the latte and my friend got the mocha latte around $3.50 each. It felt kind of like a lab experiment while watching them make our drinks with the different tools and equipment. Good techniques= good coffee. I like that they use organic milk and drip the coffee to get the best flavor. Then finish your drink with some type of artwork on top with the milk, neat. Not too hot when you first hold it in your hand, which is how good coffee should be because it's the perfect temperature for sipping. The taste is like no other, you can taste the coffee and the mixture of the milk is heaven. 

Will definitely go back if I'm in SF in the near future.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This place came highly recommended as the top spot for cappuccinos. Boy was I in for a surprise.  The Lineup was huge as it was the weekend with farmer market in full swing. 
Nevertheless I stood in line for a while and finally ordered my Cappuccino. I asked for a sweetener to put in before the pulled the shot as I like my Cappuccino this way. They didn't have any luckily I had some in my backpack and asked if they could put that one in.
The lady taking my order refused outright saying they don't allow customers to put in their sweeteners!! really!! I doubt many people carry their own sweetener on them (everyone expects a decent cafe to have them in the first place) I didn't budge as heck its my drink and I can have it the way I like and felt my request was not unreasonable. 
Finally the Barista came over and said please do as you please. 
Now for the cappuccino meh I have had much better even in SF and it was barely warm. Latte art was OK.  
I think their location draws a lot of business so they are compromising on the quality as a good espresso drink requires  attention and care IMO.
author: Elvis A.

description:
3.5 to 4 stars for the coffee, 2 stars for the madhouse line

This location is so crowded due to the tourist population, so it takes forever to get a cup of coffee. They have 2 lines, and the shorter looking one is actually slower. Took almost 30m to get coffee. I think they're so busy here that the quality isn't as good as the Mint St. location. Regular coffee came out lukewarm, but we didn't want to deal with the insane line to get a new cup. My mocha tasted pretty good but again, not as good as the other location. Don't think I'd get coffee from this location again. Madhouse!
author: Catherine N.

description:
SAY WHAT??! 

SF ALSO has good coffee?! CHUT UP! GET OUT OF THA CITEEE!!

A co-worker had recommended this coffee before my trip so when I saw a stand here at Ferry Plaza, I waited in line patiently and grabbed a bag of whole bean for home. Albeit this was probably the most expensive tiny bag of beans, but as I'm drinking it at home on the weekends. It's like gold in a cup. It's full, smooth and oh so tasty. 

My gf bought the special bag home so I'm just waiting for her to invite me over for coffee already.
author: Rae F.

description:
Bottom line...

Its great coffee and definitely worth trying once. But ONLY go if there's less than five or six people in line ahead of you. I cant understand why people wait in 30 minute queues for it. 

If nothing else there are other restaurants you can get BBC in.
author: Ash S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is entirely responsible for giving my home-brewed coffee a case of low self-esteem.

Saturday @ the Blue Bottle stand:  made-to-order cappuccino made from fresh roasted beans brewed into the perfect liquor and topped with beyond-creamy foam with a little heart shape formed on top.  I'm in love.

Sunday @ home:  peet's found in the back of the fridge, made in a French press with water-cooler hot water (not hot enough, i know), with microwaved milk to give it the essence of foam.  Eh.

Blue Bottle has a stand on the Bay Bridge side of the FM, so you can sit along the water and sip your coffee in the breeze and sunshine, with a view of the water.  It's a nice and indulgent break from the crowds.

If you want coffee quickly, this is not the place for you.  If you can wait a little while, you will do yourself a great service as you will experience what a finely crafted coffee tastes like.  Just remember, the next day you will need  to give your regular cup of joe some kind words and assurances - even if you don't feel it - 'cause it's going to know that you have lost your heart to another.
author: Liz S.

description:
Great individually-prepared drip coffee. Rich flavor, no bitterness, strong buzz. 

But not worth waiting 20 minutes. Get here before 8 a.m. or after 4 p.m. to avoid the crowds. Or use that secret kiosk window to the left. Shhhhh...
author: Mandy H.

description:
I don't know the first thing about coffee besides that Starbucks adds a lot of sugar and cream to it and I usually do too. But trying Blue Bottle Coffee's cappuccino was a seriously indulgent experience. A coffee that didn't taste atrocious without sugar, hell, tasted better WITHOUT sugar? Count me in.

Can't give it 5 stars because of how long the line is. I know it's not exactly fair for me to judge Blue Bottle when I stroll in all touristy on a Saturday morning, but 30+ minutes of waiting was a little cringe-worthy. Not to mention that there were two other Blue Bottle counters set up around the building and plaza... seems like traffic could have gone faster at the central location if they had been ferrying people to the other counters.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Delicious lattes and iced New Orleans-style coffee!

Beautiful location in the Ferry Building. Caffeine it up here before exploring any of the other vendors.
author: Connie L.

description: One of my favorite coffee shops in San Francisco.  While the coffee isn't quite as good as some of the heavy hitters like Sightglass, Barefoot, Philz, and Four Barrel, it's probably the best coffee shop in the Bay Area with enough stores to be considered a local chain.  I wish they had more iced coffee options, though, the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee has too much hickory (or something) for me.
author: Greg B.

description:
When I saw the crazy long line for this coffee place right outside the Ferry Building I was a bit cynical - how good can coffee possibly be?  I mean, I've been to Seattle, the capital of coffee in the U.S.!  But wow, this place really rocks!  It's a little coffee stand that's here for the Ferry Building Marketplace on weekends and they make individual drip coffees for each person.  Their menu is basic - with offerings like Macchiatos, Cappuccinos, Lattes, and Drip Coffee.  There's nothing sweet or blended here.  This place is truly for the hardcore coffee drinkers.

It was a warm day in norcal so I asked if they had any iced coffee.  It wasn't on the menu, but they did offer iced coffee - score!  I ordered that with soymilk.  The taste of the espresso was delicious!  It was strong and dark without tasting bitter or burnt.  I didn't even need to add any sweetener to make this a tasty drink.  Attention to detail and timing sure sets this place apart.

Be prepared to wait in line for a good 20 minutes for your coffee, but I think it's worth the wait.
author: Angela C.

description:
Non-chain like Starbucks and reminiscent of the old school cafes where they know the names/faces of regulars and the kind of drinks affixed to each one.

I love my most plain-of-all coffee orders: Cafe Latte.

They make it right each and every time, dark and brooding on the bottom, light-white and frothy cream on top.  When I swirl my straw into it, it melds like heavy cream dipping into water.

Something this smooth deserves an award.

Counter staff are very friendly, quick, and have a great memory for keeping up with those orders.
author: Miika M.

description:
Blue bottle coffee need one near the east bay!!!  Have to drive across the bridge to satisfy my coffee cravings. Iced New Orleans coffee.  

Toll $4
coffee across the bay. Priceless!!!
author: Jay B.

description:
I love coffee, but not quite enough to be a coffee connoisseur yet. However, I do know that my first time drinking Blue Bottle Coffee was pretty fantastic. If you are a native or visitor of San Francisco, know that this place is always rockin with customers (10+ minute usual wait, I'd say). For my first Blue Bottle Coffee experience, I ordered a Cafe Latte to keep it on the lighter side. Word on the street is that they drip and make their coffee in a special way. Their cups are compostable and sustainable too! I love the simple blue decor and symbol on their products. The aura of the coffee stand + lounging area is chill yet sophisticated, with a tinge of artistic decor. 

I'm excited to go back, and try their other iced / dripped coffee options. Very glad to have checked this joint out. But man, Starbucks will never be the same again...
author: Jasmine G.

description:
I have tried Blue Bottle twice and I can't figure out why everyone is raving about it.  Could it be possible I've had two "meh" experiences out of two?

First, I had regular coffee, and it was good but not great.  Yesterday, I tried a mocha, and it was lacking in both coffee and chocolate flavors.  It did, however, have a lovely little heart design floating on top.

I don't know if that's enough to get me rushing back for more.
author: Raina S.

description: Finally tried the waffle on a Thursday am. Very hot and greasy but fun to try once. Served in a coffee filter and meant to be eaten by hand - hope you have hands of steel! It's hot! Despite the long line, it goes pretty quickly and you're never wrong when selecting drip coffee or cortado from blue bottle to start the day right.
author: mary l.

description:
Cheery staff that takes their time in crafting each and every order. So love it or hate it you wont get your drink as fast as other places but rather a guarantee that it comes perfect everytime.

Note: they use Organic Clover Milk and Organic Soymilk with every drink BUT I highly recommend: 

Drip Coffee $2.75
not only is it the cheapest of the drinks available but really accentuates the full bodied roundness, richness, and pleasant clean finish. I tried the cappuccino which is great and latte as well which is good but the drip still wins hands down.

1. Drip  2. Cappuccino 3. Latte (have yet to try others)

Also their desserts are very reasonably priced, $2 for small cakes Ginger was featured today, $1 for Organic Almond Biscottis, and many others. The quality is much better than any Starbucks or Peat's and you'll pay the same if not less than what you do at these other places, so if your in the area give it a try.
author: Alex L.

description:
Not much more that I can possibly add.. amazing coffee.. well priced.. super friendly... long lines. However the cute joggers running by pass the time rather well!

Wish we had a place like this in Scottsdale.
author: Alexander C.

description:
Less 1 star because my cafe and my hubby's coffee wasn't pipin' hot.  I like it HOT damn it!  :-)

In a nut shell......

GOOD COFFEE !
LONG LINES!
DRIP = WAIT...C'MON IT'S DRIPPIN' 
FAIRLY INEXPENSIVE (considering the cost of a cup of joe these days!)
WORTH IT!

Once you go blue bottle...you don't go back!  Although I will cheat with an occasional (and more convenient Starbucks or Saxby's...but shhh don't tell BBC! hehe)
author: Angie I.

description:
Does the 15 minute long wait of anticipation make the coffee taste better? It must cause I wait in it every weekend. 

If you want your mind blown and also feel like gaining some extra weight I have one word... Affogato!!!
author: Steve K.

description:
I remembered this place because at Humphrey's they have blue bottle vietnamese coffee. 

I saw both lines...the one in the front, and the one in the back and the lines were pretty long...is this really worth it! I waited in the back line for over 10 minutes without it moving, so I decided to try the front line and it went by pretty fast.

I ordered the affogato with high expectations. It met and exceeded them. $5.50 cents for an affogato, and worth every penny. The affogato is made with esperesso and humphrey's vanilla ice cream. 

After I finished I wanted to wait in line for another.

Next time I go I'll try the Iced New Orleans Coffee.
author: Sean W.

description:
My 2nd stop while down at the Farmers' Market was the Blue Bottle Coffee tent outside next to the Rose Pistola breakfast tent. I opted for the espresso. I was really impressed that it was served in an actual espresso cup with a saucer. It reminded me of the espresso stands in Italy, but it was little more than 1 Euro. The espresso was really good and not overly bitter. I was lucky and there was only 7 people ahead of me when I got into line.

I really liked the idea behind their fresh cup by cup drip coffee also. Hearing people talk about how great the coffee is must mean it works. The downfall is prep time to make a cup of coffee though.
author: Scottie V.

description:
amazing coffee/lattes.

smooth, velvety, creamy with vanilla soy milk.  no complaints!

AND there is one in Williamsburg in NY!!!  Now they just need to open one up in Manhattan already!
author: Brittany H.

description:
Mmm... so I stood in line for a little more than 30 mins waiting for my Macchiato.

Not bad... freshly made espresso presented in a tiny little cup.

Worth the wait? - Not really...

Would I go back again? - Yes probably will... cause I am a sucker.

Brought a bag of beans to go! 

Next time, I'm gonna try Affogato... sounds delicious with ice cream.  =)
author: Pokemon P.

description: In town from the East coast for ages days, easily the best cup of coffee I've ever had.
author: D. W. S.

description:
huzzah!

best americano in san francisco!
author: Pete S.

description:
Good coffee can be so hard to come by in So Cal, I guess almost anything up North in comparison would be good but Blue Bottle Coffee is exceptional, coming in only second to my favorite, Stumptown in Portland. 

The rich, dark, aromatic brew is strong enough to sprout hair where it shouldn't be sprouting, and jolts you awake with not only the energy from the caffeine but with its fragrance and deliciousness as well. 

Blue Bottle, won't you please come down south? We could really use you around here parts...
author: Bora K.

description:
Long lines are the norm here and at pretty much every other location, but for good reason.  Blue Bottle roasts are some of the best around, and the cafe makes a mean pour-over.  I consider myself as a coffee fanatic, and I've been ordering their beans since 2007.  If you're a fan of single origin roasts, Blue Bottle usually has a good selection from Central America, Africa and Indonesia.  I've had numerous ones (Bali ones being my favorite), and none of them have disappointed.  The blends are good as well, with my favorite being the Bella Donovan (their rendition of Mocha Java blend).  

Location wise, Ferry Building (cafe and farrmers market) and Webster locations are my favorite.  The baristas are always friendly and enthusiastic when bombarded with my questions regarding the roasts.  My least favorite is the Mint Plaza location, where the people that work there aren't that friendly and have attitude.  Not sure whether somebody pees in their Cheerios every morning or what!
author: Mark Y.

description:
Yes, I will wait in line for 20 minutes.
Yes, I will wait another 15 for my coffee.
Yes , this is my FAVORITE brand of coffee.

What makes them so different???

Enjoy coffee @ its peak.
Enjoy fine organic coffee.
Enjoy the taste of freshly roasted coffee.
Enjoy the quality.

Slow dripped coffee what a delight, totally worth the wait.  My regulars are the cafe latte and cappuccino. My hubby likes the New Orleans Iced coffee which is a nice treat!
author: Gladys B.

description: Excellent medium roast coffee. Barista takes care with each drink, mine was a cap. Very long lines. Orleans style iced coffee also recommended.
author: R L.

description:
The lines here during Saturday farmers market is always incredibly long. The staff tries really hard to move people along but all three of the lines are slower, but just as long as the women's bathroom!

Unless you have a liesure weekend, go to their other locations to grab some Blue.
author: Angela B.

description: Excellent coffee...but it is ridiculous that they don't keep some sugar substitute around. There is no reason why they can't keep some alternative sweetener for people with diabetes like my mother. I do not appreciate that level of smarminess. Is it worth the wait? Definitely if you like coffee.
author: Ojas V.

description:
When did coffee ever taste this good? Blue Bottle Coffee Co. is incomparable to any chain coffee shop there is. And if you believe that Starbucks, Peets, the likes is way better... my friend, please check this place out before you embarrass yourself. I guess I can't say much considering I am a Goldcard member at Sbux, but hey! It's way cheaper than Blue Bottle. If I could afford drinking here everyday... oh my. 
Why is the coffee better? It goes down so smoothly. No bad aftertaste or watery-ness. Plus, for their drip coffee they don't use a machine but 
rather  manually drip the coffee from a wooden stand.

The artwork the workers make with the foam milk when you order lattes also make the experience more than just "getting morning coffee".

I heard their affigado is amazing and have yet to try. I'll save that for the next time I'm in the Ferry Building.
author: D S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee Co. does make a good cup of coffee...i suggest the DRIP if you are a REAL coffee fan. Its all about the taste of the actual coffee beans. People who put a lot of cream and sugar in their coffee might not really appreciate the taste. 
Im not sure i see the hype though...maybe its a SF thing....since I'm from OC i dont get the 45 min wait in line for this coffee.....but i also didn't have to wait that long either.

in retrospect, if you really appreciate coffee you will like Blue Bottle. It is reasonably priced. I didn't get anything other than the coffee, but it seems like people like their pastries...i will have to try them next time.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I'm a snob when it comes to drinking coffee but not when it comes to my treatment of people.  I've always had good service inside, but outside I had a bad experience.    After waiting in line for a relatively short period,  I stood at the counter waiting to order without being acknowledged for an extremely long time. I didn't expect anyone to wash my feet but a simple, "be with you in a minute" would have sufficed.  I almost felt like I was getting ig'd at some snooty boutique.

nevertheless, i'll probably go back but maybe I'll go inside instead
author: Ramon W.

description:
Just go try it . . This is the best I've found anywhere in the US, and I'm a serious coffee snob from Seattle . .

Be ready to wait - Weekends can be 30+ minutes in line. At first I was questioning if it was worth it, but having to wait just makes it that much more rewarding. Take along someone to talk to, or take your phone and browse porn or something . .

And really, if you're too impatient to wait 25 minutes in line while they take care of the people ahead of you, then you're not deserving . . 

PS for those who complain that "my coffee wasn't hot enough," you should learn about proper brewing temp for coffees - Most of the ultra-premium coffees they use here are correctly brewed at a much lower extraction temp, so if you're expecting MickyD's 205 degree boiler coffee, then off to MickyD's with ya all!! :)

I now order beans from them online as well. My experience with them has been all around 5 stars.
author: Senor E.

description:
I am so lucky to get to work within walking distance of the Ferry Building, and the goodness that is Blue Bottle Coffee!  I don't come here too often, as I'd like to consider this a more special treat over the everyday Starbucks or even Peet's. 

Their latte is ever so rich and smooth - and presented like a work of art - and it's no more expensive than its counterparts (big plus!) 

Also have tried their affogato - what I got was a shallow BOWL with two sizable scoops of Humphry Slocombe ice cream (oh damn!) and the hot espresso on top. It was a perfect blend of creamy vanilla and warm espresso... what a treat!
author: Jing D.

description:
We went during the crazy crowded Saturday morning farmers' market rush hour.  

NOTE:  THERE ARE 2 LINES, left and right.  GET IN THE SHORTER ONE.  I waited 40 minutes!  Duh!  Should have looked over my left shoulder.

The Afagatto is the only item worth standing in line for.  This would be 2 scoops of honey icecream topped with expresso.  Ummmmmm..... sweet and salty, warm and icy.  Perfection for this dessert diva.

As for the coffee, tastes just like dunkin donuts, which my friend says is actually better.  It's blah, bitter, almost slight sour.

Go to Philz in the city instead, smooth.....
author: Surai J.

description:
Wow, the line was pretty long for this place. It is very popular, but they are quick so you get to order relatively fast.

I got a New Orleans Iced Coffee and it was delicious. The flavor and aroma are wonderful. It is naturally slightly sweet and that is perfect because it makes it very refreshing.

I've tried Blue Bottle Coffee twice in a relatively short period of time and I must say they made me a fan.
author: Michael W.

description:
Their lattes are the smoothestttt I have EVER tasted. yum yum yum. The only bad thing about this place is the line...but it's worth it. 

Their iced coffee is also pretty good too, as well as the affogato!
author: Megha A.

description: I don't get the hype. I got a latte and my husband got the drip. They were both just okay. Not the best latte or coffee either of us have had and not worth the line.
author: Kelly T.

description:
I never knew an ice coffee ($3) can taste so good until I tried Blue Bottle.  It's a little blue booth with a long waiting line.  Well, it's not that long and it's so worth it.  This is a great starting point for the farmer market's tour.  

Forget about Starbucks, Peet's, Coffee Beans, and all those stupid chain coffee shops.  It's an insult to compare Blue Bottle with them. Everything is freshly brewed, and if you'll see how each hot coffee is individually dripped for you. 

After we finished the first drink, we found ourselves lining up for a second cup again... It's THAT good :)
author: Carina N.

description: Good, flavorful coffee without the bitterness of some and worth waiting in line on Saturdays with Farmer's Market.  Regular drip coffee is great, but they also have several...many... "exotics".  Try something new here!
author: R J.

description: On the 7x7 quest. There wasn't a huge line so I mosey over to check out the menu to find out what a gibraltar is. Menu doesn't have it so I asked the lady. I comes in a glass cup with one shot of espresso and cream. $2.75. She made it pretty fast and with a heart! WOW! It was bitter for my taste so I had to add a lot of sugar but after that it was good. The lady was really nice. 4 stars!
author: Sarah C.

description: They make every cup of coffee as it's ordered using all local ingredients. I ordered the cafe mocha and it was so smooth and delicious. Definitely a great find in the Ferry Building!
author: Melanie E.

description: Fantastic coffee. Particularly, their macchiato is amazing. Long lines, but it moves fairly quickly. The waffles are also really good, and there are a few places in the Ferry Building that can supply delicious toppings (flavored honey, etc.). Probably not a good pick if you're in a hurry but you're guaranteed to get a great cup of coffee!
author: Steve R.

description:
If you're looking for good coffee, this is the place to get it. 

I must say I'm not the most adventurous when it comes to coffee drinks, but I stick to what I know, and what I know is soy latte's.  From what I've found this joint takes the cake for best soy latte in my San Francisco hood. 

If you don't really know what you are talking about when it comes to coffee, then you're in the same boat I am, and the only reason I had to knock a star off of my rating is for the sassiness I endured when asking for a machiatto to go to take to my boss. 

Heavens forbid someone makes that mistake...

But all in all good coffee, good people, and a nice place to take a moment to relax during those hectic days.
author: Sydney C.

description:
4.5 stars but I'm rounding up. =) In my opinion this is the best coffee in San Francisco. There are several locations (Hayes Valley, Ferry Building) and some restaurants will serve Blue Bottle Coffee as well.

I've had their drip coffee, lattes, and hot chocolate which are all very good but my favorite drink has to be the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee. What I like is that you don't need to add any sugar. I've watched the baristas make it and they just have ice, coffee, and whole milk. That's it! Usually I would need to add 1 or 2 packets of coffee but not with Blue Bottle.

The only negative I have is that the prices are pretty steep. The Iced Coffee is $3.75 and the drink is not big. Their cheapest coffee drink is the Espresso, which is $2.50. The most expensive drink is the Caffe Mocha, which is $4.75. Yikes! I don't have Blue Bottle all the time so once in a while I'll treat myself.

I define good coffee as coffee you don't need to add milk, cream, or sugar to make it taste good. That's the very definition of Blue Bottle. However adding any of these things will only enhance the flavor of their coffee.
author: Therese M.

description:
Now I think they have good coffee, so if I'm here for fun, on a weekend for the farmer's market, or showing people around, this is a must have.

However, having worked in the city, this place is very inconvenient if you're taking coffee to go.  Lines are ridiculous.  I hate to have my star rating be impacted because a place is really popular, but that's just how it is.  And coffee here is almost twice as much as you'd pay at your local Starbucks or Peet's.

But definitely try it once if you haven't.  And it's fun to grab a cup and cruise around the ferry building if you're not in a hurry.
author: Ken L.

description: Impressed with the individual drip coffees. It's a medium body roast with no bitterness. No line today so service was quick.
author: Suzanne K.

description:
Stationed inside the Ferry Building, 
zippyed over in line for the AM fix. 
One coffee black made to order 
in a show-and-tell manner 
with brewing equipment doubling 
as the coffee bar's decor. 
Caffeine boiled down to an art. 

Worth the wait to make it all mine.
author: Anna K.

description:
We tookd my bf's sister and her boyfriend here to show them around SF.   They live in Seattle and was quite impressed with the way Blue Bottle made their drip coffee.  They had never seen anything quite like it and being from Seattle this was a feat.   And the taste was just as complex.  

Lines at this location is generally long but there are two windows so check out both registers before lining up.
author: Morgan L.

description: Ordered the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee.... Good, strong, slightly bitter, and definitely not sweet.  Overall, it was 4 stars and decently priced at $3.75 - it'd be hard to find THAT much cheaper coffee shops.  I took off a star because I don't think it's worth standing in line for more than 5 minutes.  If you don't want to stand in line but want to try it out, you can just buy their beans and stand in their "separate" line.  As I was just about to order, a guy holding a bag just cut in front of me while stating that their was a separate line for coffee bean only purchases. Even if there isn't really a separate line, I'm sure you can say that same and get away with it ;)
author: Stacey P.

description:
It's rich, strong, very good coffee, but only 4 stars because of the wait. I've taken visiting family and friends to the stand at the Farmer's Market.  The visitors from Rome thought I was crazy for standing in such a long line and were not impressed with the coffee.

I remain a fan, but I'm not religious about BBC.  I make it for myself at home and if I've got nothing better to do (rare) I will stand in line for a cuppa BB joe.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Let me start by saying that I am not a regular coffee drinker. I enjoy it, but don't need caffeine. So I'm selective about the coffee I drink and Blue Bottle is consistently smooth and tasty. Seems it's no secret though. There is usually quite a line, but it moves fast enough.

Yes Blue Bottle!
author: Susan W.

description:
They say that there's a line to heaven.... Coffee heaven is apparently no different. 

I don't know what else to say about this place that already hasn't been said. They take their coffee seriously, and it shows in the finished product. It's delicious, doesn't taste burnt, rich.... blah blah blah. 

Look, I stood in line with 20 other people in the pouring rain. My wife thought I was crazy. I figured if I'm going to be walking around SF in the pouring rain then I was going to do it with a damn good cup of joe in hand. It was well worth the wait.
author: Victor H.

description:
In heaven, when you arrive at the Pearly Gates, there is a massive Blue Bottle and when you step up to the counter you have your own angel-barista who just hands you an enormous New Orleans Iced Coffee in a real tall glass, and as you sip it, it never really empties, it just stays full, icy, rich, and smooth.

Here on Earth, we have to make a deal with the devil in the form of a sometimes nightmarish line, followed by a long wait to receive the coffee, followed by standing behind some mouth breather who is bogarting the simple syrup, while your New Orleans Iced Coffee is rapidly reducing the paper cup to mush.

It's a price I will pay, though, here on Earth, because this is seriously good coffee.
author: Kevin S.

description: Had their affogato and I did not like it at all.  The coffee was super strong & bitter.  I usually like strong coffee, but not like this.  I think maybe the ice cream/coffee ratio was off, it might've been better with more ice cream.
author: Sofie D.

description:
Call me crazy, but I was totally underwhelmed (especially after reading all the 4 and 5 star reviews)... Philz Coffee kicks this place in the butt (not even close in my mind), and I'm not even sure the coffee here was at Starbucks level.
I had the mocha and I could barely taste the coffee.. and the Nawlins iced coffee was meh...
Also had the waffle. Wasn't bad, but wasn't great either...
Definitely not worth the crazy lineup for... nor the expensive price!
author: D T.

description: My transition from Italy to America was a bit difficult considering I would drink a caffe latte every day and I was afraid i would NEVER find something that would work as a replacement. Long story short, the drink was amazing (at Bue Bottle) and is the closest imitation I've had in America to the real caffe latte's of Rome. The price was fair and the serving size was great. They add cute little designs on top of the coffee with the milk which always makes me smile. I can't vouch for the drip coffee as I've never had it before but people seem to love it. Great and easy location, gets a bit busy at times but the wait is never more than 15 minutes. A must for all caffe latte lovers.
author: Tommy C.

description:
Expensive but worth it.

Organic Clover Milk and the quality of beans used make this a nice treat. They use a manual espresso machine which produces a different level of richness to your coffee. 

The girl was super friendly, very nice. Slow service, but very fresh. 

Prices are high, so don't go every day but indulge once in a while on a lazy Sunday.
author: Ghesline B.

description: One of San Francisco's best espressos & roasters.  I regularly purchase their roasts for home use and visit their SF/NYC shops whenever I'm in the area.  There's not much to say about Blue Bottle that hasn't already been said.  If you're looking for consistently high quality espressos or to purchase beans for home use, Blue Bottle is definitely recommended.
author: Lee R.

description: Really enjoyed the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee! Could drink that every day if I wasn't worried my heart would give out from going into a caffeine-overdrive.
author: Jessie M.

description: People watch in the pretty Ferry Building while you stand and stand and then stand some more. Then get the best cuppa you've had in a while. If you are in a rush, skip over to Peet's my darlin.
author: Helen K.

description:
the belgium waffle! the belgium waffle! the belgium waffle!

this one of the best things i've ever eaten with my hands. Its fluffy, sweet, but not too sweet. moist. crunchy, warm, yummy. Plus its only $3 - which you may think 'thats alot of a waffle!' and it would be for A waffle, but Blue Bottle's Belgium Waffle is worth it - trust me if you know whats good for ya. I might have to go all next week to have more. Oh and It just takes a few minutes for them to make fresh! instant satisfaction.

oh and the coffee isnt so bad either. 
i especially like the New Orleans Iced Coffee :)
author: Cicely T.

description: OMG!!!  NEW best coffee I've ever had.  Staff was so helpful and knowledgeable.  So excited to see there is one in Chelsea, NYC.  Totally worth the 15 minute wait in the line.
author: Jenise C.

description: Visited SF and my coffee fanatic friends insisted we had to make a visit at least once before heading back to TX. So much hype over this place! So many people... I stood in line for 10 minutes for a cup of coffee! Maybe it's because I'm not a huge coffee drinker so I can't fully appreciate like some others...who knows. The New- Orleans style ice coffee was really good though! It was so smooth and refreshing and I'm glad I tried it. Don't know if Blue Bottle is worth all the hype, it's certainly not the best coffee in the world, but that's just me.
author: Winnie C.

description: The best cafe latte...PERIOD.  I wonder if the difference is the organic milk that they use.
author: Sunil R.

description:
All the baristas here do lovely latte art.  Everyone knows blue bottle is good because of the quality of the beans and the roasts.  The individual drips and their espresso machine there bring it to another level, and the clover creamery dairy makes each latte extra rich and smooth.  There's no hint of acidity or bitterness to any of their hand crafted drinks.

Even more special is their baked goods, which are unique to Blue Bottle.  Today, I had the arborio rice cake, which is one of the most innovative pastry/desserts I've had in a while.  It looks like any other loaf from afar, but once you get a closer look, you'll appreciate the dried fruit bits and actual grains of arborio inside.  It's super moist, with extra texture from chopped nuts, and it has just the right balance of fruitiness and anise flavor.  I love that the pastries are handed to you in a coffee filter, too.

There are a couple seats around this corner shop at the ferry market building, and it's nice that it's not as crazy crowded.  Blue Bottle makes the bay area proud.
author: Marilyn T.

description: Love the iced coffee here, although a cup of Peet's Baridi Iced Coffee around the corner is just as satisfying and involves much less of a wait. The service is mostly friendly. I get that Blue Bottle is for the coffee nerds (of which I admittedly am one), but I think they would gain by being a little more approachable to the everyday person.
author: Kel S.

description: Although I'm from Seattle, I don't consider myself a coffee snob.  I'm happy drinking the coffee usually provided at the theater during rehearsal, or even gas station mini-mart blend while on a road trip.  But I do like a nicely prepared espresso drink every now and then, and the Blue Bottle stand at the Ferry Building is a great place to enjoy a shot of espresso or a macchiato.  Ironically, Blue Bottle's secret seems to be slightly burning the beans when roasting, which is similar to the original Starbucks "Full City" roast.   Starbucks has moved away from that style, so if you enjoy a dark, chocolaty coffee flavor check out Blue Bottle!
author: Rob W.

description:
We're a Blue Bottle Household through and through.  My favorites are the Cup of Excellence, though sadly they run out.  I'm really digging the Wallenford Estate JBM, and at $18 for a half pound, I brew mine in the siphon.  This is one damn fine bean.  It's hard to find JBM, and when you do, it's very, very pricy.  Jamaican Blue Mountain is my favorite coffee ever.

They've also got some crazy COE right now that is $32/half pound.  Yeah, I am a coffee fanatic, but that's too rich for my blood.  I'm curious to try it out.

Also, if you just buy beans, you can skip the line and just pay for the beans.

I'm a total bitch without my coffee.  It's my drug of choice, and Blue Bottle is my dealer.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
I don't like coffee.  I like the smell of it, I like to bake with it, but I don't like drinking it.  Nevertheless, when I moved here, I promised a friend that I would try Blue Bottle with an open mind.  The first time I passed by, there were 20 people in line.  A few weeks later, I did hop into line and ordered a cup of the drip coffee.  Simply put, according to my noobie coffee taste buds, it was easily the best cup of coffee I have ever had.

PS - The first time I passed by, I was curious what that smell was.  I was surprised to find out that it was a Blue Bottle.  It was so much deeper and richer than what I normally expect coffeehouses to smell like.
author: Kipy K.

description:
Finally tried Blue Bottle after hearing a ton of hype. It was late, so I had a decaf latte. Fantastic!!! None of that bitter aftertaste you get with many other mattes. Loved it. Also: friendly service and a pretty swirly design on the top! Way to make me grin, latte lady! :) 

(btw: The nearest parking is the 15.00 lot across the street and up half a block.)
author: Karen Z.

description: I fear that my rating is not fair, being that I'm a decaf coffee drinker, but there is a reason the line is long.  It did move quick.  They created a decaf Americano for me, and I have had better.  However, I can give them some major kudos on their snickernoodles.  Delicious! They offer a unique variety that is laced with saffron, giving the interior a beautiful hue and a faint honey flavor.  Paired with the other spices, the cookie was awarded #1 snickerdoodle for its sheer unique qualities and earthy loveliness.  You do not get that complexity with most baked goods, but it pairs wonderfully with a coffee.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Best mocha I've ever had. Period. The Barista did a leaf design in my foam, too. :) My husband's coffee was awesome - they pour over your coffee when you order it. Very fresh.
Love this place!
author: Sarah S.

description:
The most delicious coffee I've had in a long time, and I've been living in Seattle. (Supposedly the coffee capitol, but I beg to differ now that I've had this).
I had a soy latte, and it was the sweetest, most delicious, palate pleasing coffee. (Soy because I'm lactose intolerant, I think I saw them use Pacific soy). 
My latte to go was served up with a beautiful rosette. I want to go back now... even to just get a cup of drip.
author: April L.

description: i love coffee and this place hits the mark. delish espresso
author: Laurence K.

description:
So I like coffee, being Chilean I have been drinking coffee and milk before it was cool to drink coffee and milk - lattes.  I'm not a coffee snob, really : -)
So my co workers have been telling me about how smooth the coffee is here and they are 100% right.  No bitterness, no after taste, just smooth all around.  They made the leaf design and it was pretty cool. 

We had a couple of the Snickerdoddles, which were really good.  I work on Beale Street and will be dropping in a lot more.
author: Hugo E.

description:
This is my 1st stop before I check out the free samples at the Farmer's Market.  If it's warm, I get the New Orleans coffee with chicory.  If it's cool out, then I get a cup of hot coffee.  

The hot coffee is brewed by manually pouring hot water over the grounds in a paper filter.  The cup is placed directly under that filter.  No machine.  Then you can add your organic half and half or sugar.  For just $2, this is high quality coffee and no waiting for the next brew or taking care of various lattes ahead of you.

They usually have 2 set up on Saturday morning: just south of the main entrance and then near the south entrance by the cooked foods.
author: Jay N.

description: Late was great and didn't need any additions :)
author: Sharon S.

description:
I am a coffee addict. No not the caramel frappuccino crap, i mean real coffee and espresso. Not that I'm an expert, becoming one probably would require me to have tasted hundreds of different beans, but I don't think my tongue can even differentiate that many flavors to begin with. I do know a good coffee when I taste it though, and this place does coffee justice!

So far I have tried their drip coffees and their New Orleans Iced coffee. Both are really good, so on cold days I'll opt for the drip and hot days definitely go with the new orleans. My friend also bought some of their coffee beans and their ceramic drip cup, as well as a grinder. I personally really like Giant Steps. Three Africans is pretty good too. Their more on the bold side, but it's nice because each bag has its own description so you can pick based on your preference. 

Also, if you are craving something sweet to eat with the coffee, their belgian waffles are amazing! Warm, fresh, crisp on the outside with a really nice and not too sweet glaze, and they serve it to you in a filter paper bag, which I think is pretty neat. Coffee + waffle = perfect start to a perfect day in the bay. =] 

warning: the lines get really long, but it's worth it for the coffee and they try to serve you as fast as they can.
author: Grace C.

description: I got up early this morning and walked over to the ferry building when lo and behold the blue bottle coffee line was the shortest ive ever seen it! Decided this was my chance to finally try this infamously best coffee of san francisco. It more than lived up to any hype! I tried the hand dripped coffee and it had a bold flavor with hardly any acidity. Im hooked!
author: Danielle M.

description: My husband has been raving about this coffee and I finally got to try it. My cappuccino was frothy and delicious. Moreover, the heart-shaped foam was beautiful!  For me, the temperature was perfect for drinking immediately, but my husband prefers his extra hot and it's definitely not that. If you are in a hurry find a Starbucks on any corner, but if you love a quality cup of joe, it's worth the wait.
author: Joyce D.

description:
Dear Blue Bottle, 

You think you can just pocket-check me whenever you like?  You think you can take all my hard earned money and whip me up these unbelievable cups of joe that make my heart race, my hands shake and give me a jolt of energy so i can get some work done?  Well, you got another thing coming BB.  I dont care that your New Orleans iced coffee is like a sweet melody wrapped around my tongue.  Or that  those cute hearts you make atop my cappuccinos make me all warm and fuzzy and shit.  Or that i use to order online and brew at home because a nice cup of black coffee from you is just as mouth-pleasing.  Oh, you finally decided to open a spot up in the Ferry Building because you know its within walking distance to me?  Well la di freakin da, I could care less. 

Oh hell, i'll see you tomorrow...and the next day...and the next day....and the next day after that.  Im an addict, what?

Signed,
Me.
author: Juv C.

description: I didn't realize this was a San Francisco chain until I started writing this review, but man, I wish I had known.  I loved the coffee here, I loved the people working.  I just loved everything about it.  If I lived in San Fran, this would be my go-to coffee shop.  Yum!
author: Joanna F.

description:
I don't even like coffee, but I ABSOLUTELY LOVE Blue Bottle. Every time I go to the Ferry Building, I must make a stop here. It's a refreshing break from that overly-sugared Starshmucks crap they call coffee (I hate their coffee, and think most every cup of coffee they sell tastes like dirt). This is the real deal.

I ordered a latte, since I like my coffee light. If you know me, a couple of sips of coffee and I'm up-the-wall wired!!. One word came to mind: delightful. The coffee to milk ratio was just perfect, and the froth had just the right density and lasted me throughout my entire cup. I like that.

I liked it so much, my boyfriend and I went back later that day and helped ourselves to an espresso. Oh gawd, I can still remember the velvety smoothness of that perfect concoction. Now, one reason why I don't like coffee is because of the nasty aftertaste in the back of my mouth. I didn't have an issue with that after having drunk their espresso. Instead, I was pleasantly surprised at how I could still taste the coffee bean and feel the natural oils coat my tongue. Mmm..
author: Trinity G.

description: I'm not a huge coffee drinker but sometime you just need the caffeine. This place is not the quickest place to get your fix in the area but they make a solid cappuccino. There's a main line and a side window, both of which you can order from, but the main line moves twice as fast and enough people have found out about the side window that it's not always faster anymore (but still worth checking!).
author: Jason C.

description:
Might be the best beans and roast I've ever had. So buy your beans here. 

The service is slow, but when you have product like this...hard to beat. 
If you like your coffee drinks hot, ask them to make them a little extra hot. I'm less for tepid cappuccino that they seem to like to serve them (multiple times). 

That all said...did I mention this could be the best coffee I've ever had? Buy the beans.
author: Mark H.

description: Yes we all love this coffee.  Few of us still drink plain old black drip coffee.  Even fewer of us refuse to wait for it.  I don't wait...just keep walking.  They used to sell the brilliant little Beehouse ceramic drip makers for you to make coffee at home...now they sell something inferior with their logo screened on it.  Classy move.  But, if you do decide to wait - it's good.
author: David S.

description: I just wrote a review for this location because it's the one I end up most of the time it seems like. Simply the coffee here is the best I've found in San Francisco.
author: Brendan B.

description: The Blue Bottle 'secret window' is my usual stop after a burger at 4505 or a take-out from Out the Door. Takes forever, but the ritual is part of what makes Blue Bottle so good.
author: Robert M.

description: Delicious =) Nothing like getting a cup of drip coffee and heading to the bench outside of the Ferry Building overlooking Treasure Island while having a lovely conversation with a friend.
author: Aaron H.

description:
I usually go here to get an ice coffee when I'm there for the Tuesday farmer's market.  I am not sure how they make it but I think it is very good.  The only bad thing is that there are usually a bunch of ground up beans at the bottom. I'm not sure if it is intentional or not, but getting some grounds with your sip bothers you, the last centimeter or so of coffee won't be enjoyed.  

This is probably the best coffee I've found in San Francisco. I'm from Seattle and am very particular about my coffee.  I usually get my beans sent down from my favorite places in Seattle but will get beans here once in a while. Definitely worth a stop though if you enjoy your espresso in actual espresso glasses and want more of a coffee experience than you get at any of the chains.  It isn't cheap though.
author: Hanley B.

description: I'm not a huge coffee fan, but I come here for one reason. Can you say affogato!
author: Charles N C.

description: I love how each cup of coffee is personally brewed with a little friendly chat :) Makes the wait worth every minute or should I say each of the 30 minutes I waited haha I had ordered the cafe mocha in a small cup and it was prepared with some latte art to top it off. A perfect treat to have while browsing the Ferry building farmer's market :)
author: Katrina D.

description:
Indeed there's always a wait for something extraordinary like Blue Bottle Coffee.

I ordered a mocha and I must admit it was the most creamy mocha I've ever had in my life and not too sweet nor strong.  

They even use real fudge!

I thought it was awesome that they serve your drinks with an espresso cup.
author: Sophia S.

description:
I have heard a lot of good things about the blue bottle coffee. I finally had a chance to try it today after bay to breakers.

The blue bottle coffee shop was pretty well organized. It was busy, but the line moved fairly quickly. I ordered 2 coffees: a regular drip coffee and a new orleans style iced coffee.

The first coffee came pretty quickly, but they forgot about the second one. I got it pretty quickly when I asked about it. So the service of this place is pretty swift; however, I noticed that people there didn't  really smile and seem very happy. In term of the drink, there's really nothing special. I have definitely had better coffee elsewhere in the bay area, so the place was overhyped.

All in all, if I wanted a quick cup of coffee from unhappy overworked employees, I could have gone to places like dunkin donut; or I could have gone to Starbucks if I wanted a nicer environment. Unfortunately the world doesn't need another brand like Starbucks or dunkin donut.
author: Chris F.

description:
** In protest of the Dolores Park cart debacle, I am giving 5 stars to all the Blue Bottle kiosks where I get coffee.  Three Africans all the way!  Sorry you had to deal with the haters Blue Bottle. **

Plus, thank you to the sweet lady who let me know that if you're just getting beans you can go up to the side of the cart and ask.
author: Tullia F.

description: My go-to coffee when I'm in the city.  I last had the latte at the Ferry Building location and while the line was fairly long, it moved very quickly.  Tip: line up on the other side, not on the main hall as that gets very long :).
author: Em D.

description: On a recent trip to San Fran we discovered the Ferry Building on Embarcadero...what an awesome place!  We stopped for a latte at this stand one morning, and it was amazing.  Quality ingredients, friendly people, very reasonable prices, and of course gorgeous latte art!  If I lived in the City I would come all the time!!!!
author: Rebecca P.

description:
I'm torn about this. I heard such amazing things about Blue Bottle before visiting SF. I was so excited, and yet so let down. I thought it was the simplest order - decaf. They couldn't do it. I had to get an Americano. This completely baffled me. 
 
But, I do have to say - I usually very much dislike Americanos. However, I really liked this one. 

I just don't understand why they can't do a decaf drip. On their website they sell a Swiss Water Process Decaf - "Decaf Noir".

Oh well.
author: Sarah R.

description: This place kills me.  The coffee is good, on par with other top espresso joints in SF.  Nothing too special (i.e. Philz level). However, it is run with the efficiency of a snail going through molasses in Greenland.  It's like the owners tried to figure out how to sell as little coffee as possible.  The line is always insanely long and moves extremely slowly.  You will spend most of your day waiting, even at off-peak hours.  Only once have I had the Lance Armstrong-like stamina needed to wait til the end.  The other 10 times I've thrown up my hands with a "Damn you, Blue Bottle!" and stormed off in frustration.  Good coffee that's worth waiting 5 minutes for, but not an hour.  A bit overhyped.  Skip it unless you happen to come when the line is abnormally short.
author: Nick D.

description:
I LOVE this coffee.....it's so smooth and rich tasting.......
and doesn't leave me all zooted up like Starbucks coffeee.
author: Monster E.

description: To the lovely bearded man who made me a drink from the Blue Bottle secret menu this morning; may flowers grow everywhere you step.  From the bottom of my tired heart; thank you for caffeinating me while I waited for my drop coffee.  You are my hero. xo
