author: Jessica T.

description: Not a coffee drinker, but the barrista doing the Latte Art was as personable as can be, and it was a work of art. Fascinating.
author: George T.

description:
Ok 5 stars from me for a coffee place is um... REALLY good.  I'm by no means a regular drinker.  I get the shakes with decaf and I'm not into feeling a buzz for the heck of it.

My coworker had me come along with to get a cup of this "really good coffee" one fine afternoon.  Hmmm I didn't see any "decaf" on the board what to do what to do I though.  Oh heck ok I'll just order a mocha.  I prepared for no sleep and insomnia that night with a sprinkling of the jitters but low and behold none of that.  Why?  I'm intrigued as to why BBC coffee doesn't have the same affect that say Starbucks and Petes has on me.  Scary but good.  Their coffee is definitely smooth in taste and I like the fact that they use clover organic milk.  Drum roll please.... the question many ask "is it worth the extra money and time".... the answer is 'YES.'
author: Alicia W.

description:
Three reasons to brave the crowds of tourists and go to Blue Bottle at the Ferry Bldg:

1.) Super smooth coffee: drink it black, you won't need sugar or milk- it's that good. 

2.) Hot baristas: Super cute strawberry blonde guy with long pony tail. Dark curly haired guy with one long dred. Both are equally skilled baristas (baristos?) able to whip up a caffeinated beverage of your choice.

3.) Grab your coffee and go to People Donuts near Sur de Table and purchase a salted caramel donut to accompany it... OR sit outside, sip your coffee, and look out at the Bay.
author: Laura B.

description:
I love coffee and knew I had to check out Blue Bottle.  It certainly lives up to all the hype.  I love the special touches like the artistic touches from the steamed milk and the guarantee of freshly roasted beans.

I think I'm about commit some sort of coffee sacrilege here, but what they've really proven here is that you don't need a coffee maker or french press at home.  Just drill a hole through the bottom of a mug, insert filter and voila - blue bottle individual drip at home.
author: Caroline C.

description: Their coffee really is "all that." if they have the caramelized Belgium waffle available; get it! Hot off the griddle, this thing is redic.
author: Brent A.

description: Having worked in the coffee business, the coffee is superb, top of the line. Having worked in the coffee business, if the baristas were any more hipster cool, un-customer friendly, rude, bitchy, full of themselves & drink making know it alls no one would be a repeat customer. If you don't like working early and being customer friendly, then go get another job.
author: Kent L.

description:
NEW ORLEANS STYLE ICED COFFEE was awesome! :) Great flavor and finish, no bitterness at the end like some other coffeeshops. 

(We asked if the "Kyoto style iced coffee" was available, per "the best thing I ever drank" show... but, was not...)
author: Judy N.

description:
I
Turned
Down 
Peet's 
Coffee.

Yes, it's a rare occassion when I'll pass by Peet's in the morning when I've not caffeinated.  This particular morning, I was on a mission to find Blue Bottle -- another Yelp bookmark for goodness knows how long.  I've read about this coffee and I needed to see if it was as good as the legend.  My husband, the former barista, was with me.  Both of us declared that some GOOD coffee!

This is what yelpers have been raving about.  And I like it A LOT!  It is worth the wait, for sure.  I sent my husband to buy the coffee and I took my son inside to buy him a drink.  By the time we were back, he was still waiting.  But it is WORTH the wait.

And in case Peet's gets jealous that I "cheated" with another, don't worry... by the end of that morning, I'd gotten a cup from you (though not at the Ferry building)
author: Patty W.

description: There was seating yay! I love the ferry building. The coffee was strong and just okay but I loved the design! I put a ton of sugar in mine lol and more milk. If you want a pretty appearance request it to be in a cup for here! disappointed that there is little seating you dont get that coffee house feel
author: Diane S.

description: Lines are super long.  I usually get latte or ice coffee here.
author: Byron L.

description: Wow really great coffee.  I had an espresso one day and a cappuccino the other and was blown away each time.  The staff were younger hipsters with great attitudes.  Quick service with a smile..a tad pricey but worth it for an occasional treat.
author: Wade V.

description:
The americanos are amazing. The granola is incredible. The cookies are otherworldly. The waffles are mind blowing. The lattes are perfection.

The line in the Ferry Building can get a little outrageous on the weekends, but Blue Bottle is the perfect spot for a mid week morning or afternoon coffee/snack break.
author: Brian D.

description: Unbelievably bad. Come on, folks. Calibrate the machine. Clean it. That was the worst shot I've been served since desperation took me to an airport Starbucks. It's not rocket science.  Quit insulting us.
author: Judy C.

description:
I buy coffee at an astronomical rate. I prefer Starbuck's to Pete's for the most part (but will do either and even Tully's in a pinch). But the best coffee bar in the city is the Blue Bottle in the Ferry Building. During non-Farmers' Market hours, the one inside is great. During the Saturday Farmers' Market the crew on the outside stand at the edge of the Market (near Rosa Pistola and the pork guy) is your best bet since that is the sunny side of the market and you'll need some sun while you wait.
Even if you never order mochas, do it at Blue Bottle. They use chocolate that is vegan, organic, local and has unicorn tears or something. I could care less about all that, but it is insanely good and compliments the coffee in an amazing fashion.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Got to try (and still enjoying) coffee spot 1 of 2 (Philz) up here in the city and it lived up to the hype.  I can appreciate a coffee place that takes a lot of pride in its coffee (individual drips per cup), as well as using other local establishments (Humphry Slocombe ice cream for the affogato).  

I needed a pick me up and looked to a iced latte @ Blue Bottle.  As I'm approach full blown wired, this is not disappointing.  For the same price as Peet's or Starbucks, you can get a more flavorful and rich coffee experience @ Blue Bottle and also not feel bad for giving in to the corporate coffee world :)
author: Jeff N.

description:
I tried the New Orleans iced coffee. I think I still enjoy Philz more, but I gotta try the others next time I'm back in the city :)


Long ass line though.
author: Jamie C.

description:
coffee: i love blue bottle...and i love this location tons :)  delish lattes and cappucinos...and i love their waffles 

service: wonderful

final thoughts: i wish i lived in sf so i can drink blue bottle coffee everyday
author: Kara P.

description:
Meh. 

It's good, very strong, but it isn't so great that I have time to wait 20 minutes.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Internal Dialogue:

Pro Me: What is that line?  Are they giving away free Brie?  Ooooh, Blue Bottle Coffee.  So this is what all those yelpers have been raving about...Hm

Anti Me: You have alot to do today!  The last thing you have time to do is sit in a long ass stupid line for some coffee you won't even like.  You know you only drink Starbucks, why are you even contemplating this.

Pro Me: Hm.  Maybe I should check this out.  David's at daycare and I am off early, why not take a few minutes to try something new and interesting.  It must be something special with all these suits and ties waiting in line.

Anti Me: YOU ARE NOT GOING TO LIKE IT!  You know you only like Starbucks.  You don't even like Peets!  And EVERYONE likes Peets!  Just stick to what you know, save your money and your time.

Pro Me:  Hm.  Should I get the Affoghato or the Latte.  I don't even know what an Affoghato is, I just see Humphrey Schlome listed next to it and me likey's that weird ass Humphrey Slocombe shit.

Anti Me: Hello Lard Ass!  You still need to lose 10 lbs, remember!  If you must do this, just get a nonfat Latte.  Oh no!  You can't get it nonfat!  Only Whole Milk!  RUN!  Your ass is expanding just contemplating this.

Pro Me: Its sunny outside, its been a long treacherous week, I can treat myself to a whole milk Latte. 

Anti Me: But if you get a Whole Milk Latte how are you going to properly judge the latte, you will be persuaded by the whole milk!  

Pro Me: And that's not a bad thing is it.  

Pro Me:  Those men working the counter are quite attractive.  Wow.

Anti Me:  Those men working the counter are quite attractive.  Wow.

Pro Me:  And nice.

Anti Me: And nice.

Me: Can I have a latte...for here.  

Am I hallucinating or is this the best Latte I have ever had...maybe since my trip to Italy.  Is it the milk or is it the coffee....its the coffee.  Strong but not overpowering, mild but present taste and a palatable richness.  This is what got me hooked on Latte's in the first place.
author: Rosie C.

description: I have to admit I am addicted to this place.  Staff is kinda' friendly but you don't get the "warm and fuzzies" with them.  However, the coffee is amazing.  Probably the best in San Francisco.   Parking is always a challenge but great place to go if you're with a buddy and are walking or biking.  I am usually there at least twice a week.
author: Tony P.

description:
Really enjoyed the rich chocolate-y mocha.  (Personal preference, I like it a bit sweeter than their standard, but that was easy to adjust with the simple syrup they provide.)  Love the thick creamy foam on top, with the handcrafted design.  

For those that don't like the lines, you are probably going to wait ANYWHERE that's decent in the mornings...why not go for something more interesting than the commercial standbys??
author: Amy M.

description:
With nicotine being regulated, taxed and shunned out of existence there are essentially  two legal drugs left:  alcohol and caffeine.  I like to think of myself as an aficionado of both. Aficionado has a much sweeter ring than addict, no? 

If I ever get convicted of a capital crime, a cup of Jamaican Blue Mountain will be a part of my final menu (it will chase the bacon infused Old Fashioned I just discovered).

But short of that $120 per pound deliciousness, BB is the best coffee I've  had.  And yes a 30+ minute wait at 8.30 AM is a bit ridiculous and yes $2+ for 10 ounce cup is a bit much, but damn it's good.

I do wish this location did the siphon coffee like the one down on Jessie St. but it's just as well because I don't need to spend $10 on a cup of coffee too regularly.
author: Jay W.

description: First of all, the location in Ferry Plaza is legit. Totally legit. This may sound odd, but I like being able to get fresh shucked oysters with my coffee. As for the goods, the coffee is many notches above Starbucks and in fact, a few above most small coffee houses as well. They really figured it out. Drip coffee and oh so creamy. If they had this in New York City, the line would be around the corner. Believe it.
author: Amik A.

description: Coffee here is great of course (hence the long lines).  Not sure if it is worth the extra mulah and waiting in lines especially on the weekends or during farmer's market, but walking along the pier while drinking your coffee makes up for it!
author: Peter S.

description: The wife and I decided to try a drink here as we've always seen long lines whenever we visit the Ferry building..  We got a mocha with about a 15 minute wait.  We liked the drink but we are not coffee experts so we couldn't say this mocha was way better than any other mocha.  They serve drip coffee at reasonable prices.  Good place to get a cup of joe.
author: Ralph O.

description:
2.5 stars.  Sure, the coffee is good, but the service is just not...  I haven't done a Yelp review in ages, but after reading this story in the NYT, I felt compelled to say something about the service at Blue Bottle:
http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/05/nyregion/black-cow-coffee-company-in-pleasantville-review.html?_r=1&src=rechp
Just be pleasant, and don't act like it's an honor for me to be served by your hipster asses, ok?  Drip is starting to be the norm in SF, so you need to put a little extra into making your establishment friendly.  On a recent Saturday I witnessed the baristas acting very annoyed with someone for accidentally spilling a coffee and then taking FOREVER to get her another one... Then the hungover chick making the drips completely forgot who should get the next drip coffee as we all patiently waited while she called out the names of folks who already got theirs.  IF your only job is to pour water over ground coffee, can't you keep your stuff straight?  I'm so sick of the entitled and horrible attitudes of so many SF SERVICE PEOPLE!
author: robyn s.

description:
I love the iced coffee here.... yum.

I also tried the HK Egg Sandwich for breakfast... it it served on BIG TEXAS TOAST but no crust...... very cute... the way moms usually make their sandwiches for their kids :)

The egg is simple.. scrambled fluffy egg well seasoned with salt and ground pepper.
author: Jennie L.

description: Blue Bottle may be all the rage up in northern California, as it's basically the bay area equivalent of the oh-so-hip but oh-so-amazing Intelligentsia. The difference here however, is Intelli gets five stars in my book but Blue Bottle falls a little flat. The lines at Blue Bottle are pretty long, but I can't always say that it is worth the wait. While their espresso is good, I find that it lacks some of the complexity and depth that I can get from other Bay area roasters like Sightglass or Four Barell. The staff is friendly, but the baristas aren't always the best out there. Blue Bottle can be found all over the city, which I guess is cool, but the acidity in their coffee is not as well balanced as I would like.
author: Frances L.

description:
Drip coffee - best coffee I've ever had.
Bonus: hit the place when only two people were in line.
author: Jen D.

description:
Single latte or cappuccino straight to the point.  No frills, no grande-grande here!!!

This is a treat for me when I come early to the Ferry Building after a morning workout.  
If you don't get here early you will be waiting in line for a while.

We purchase the 17ft Ceiling and Hayes Valley Espresso for our morning brew.
author: Emet S.

description:
I had to see what all the hype was about.
So i stood in a long line in the rain....and i found out...

that i've been drinking CRAP COFFEE all my life!

i dont really know how to describe it in words, but i thought i knew what good coffee tasted like...and apparently i didnt!!!

smooth, rich, tasty, and worth a long wait and the semi high price.  I cant wait for the actual store to open up in the ferry building, so i wont have to wait in line outside =)
author: Gladys D.

description:
Dammit. Blue Bottle's lattes have ruined me for all others. I think I might have to find a job there so I can learn to make the magic myself. So dang good.

I guess I've been rendered (mostly) speechless. I just walk around drinking (the latte!) and thinking "Thank you, thank you, thank you" to the coffee gods -- I'm so grateful to be here, now, with my cup of Blue Bottle bliss.
author: J. C.

description: Espresso of the highest quality, made with care.  Sooo good.  Perfection in a demitasse cup.
author: Pete J.

description: My taste for coffee must have changed.  Cannot stand the bitterness of their iced coffee.  One sip and I was done.
author: Chloe H.

description: Save yourself the ridiculous line inside and grab a coffee at the stand.  Coffee is just as good and you wait 10 minutes instead of 25.  Their espresso is delicious, but I really go for the New Orleans Iced which no one else seems to make.
author: Sally L.

description: Wow! If you are a coffee conosour, check this place out.
author: Moy V.

description: Yes, there is a long line, and there will always be one for Blue Bottle.. because it's so damn good!  The staff always try to make the line goes by as efficiently as possible- there was a barista taking orders down the line to reduce the wait for drip coffee.  I've been to other Blue Bottle coffee locations, and this one definitely hits my (rather well-caffeinated) heart as well.  My friend and I stopped by on a 80-degree Saturday, and the New Orleans iced coffee was perfect, and a great wake-up call to farmers market shopping!
author: Tiffany K.

description: The coffee is fantastic. The wait can be a bit long, but you can say that about most things in the ferry building.
author: Captain B.

description: Had to try this place since it is one of San Fran's most popular coffee shops.  The regular latte was perfect...not bitter, not too sweet.  Didn't have to add anything to my latte which is how it should be if it's made well.
author: Brian L.

description: 5 stars for the Blue Bottle Affogato with Humphry Slocombe ice-cream. Only bummer is the long and slow line. But once that affogato hits the lips... oh, its so worth it!!!
author: Jessica W.

description: Their mocha and parmesan/fennel/sea salt shortbread kicks ass!
author: Irene C.

description:
When I read that Blue Bottle is the "coffee cathedral" I knew I had to check it out. After one sip, I knew I hit the coffee jackpot!

Why Blue Bottle stands out:
1. SMOOTH. Their cappuccinos are so smooth. There is no lingering bitterness that other coffees leave in your mouth.
2. Simple syrup. They have a bottle of simple syrup in addition to regular sugar. No need to wait for the sugar to dissolve!
3. Love how every cup looks like a work of art.
4. Affogatos! I don't think that you can get an affogato at any other coffee house in the city!

The only downside: you're so spoiled at Blue Bottle that you can go anywhere else!
author: Lauren T.

description: For the coffee, this is a five star. There are some cons to the place but I was there for a take out americano so the cons are irrelevant. I went twice today. The second time they were using the Rwanda Peaberry beans. I have no ability to withstand any acidity so this just did not work for me. What got me hooked was the first visit where they used the Roman Espresso beans. The description for the Roman includes the word "caramel".  This is just a downright holy s**t great coffee for those of us who's palate rejects acidity. They brewed it "ristretto" and if they stayed to the other instructions it would have been at a lower temp and longer extraction. Whatever they did do it was magic and I hope to reproduce it in some small way at home. btw, 1/2 pound beans was only $8.
author: Rob K.

description: pleasantly surprised to have found this coffee stand at the ferry building. I've had blue bottle coffee before at Plant Cafe next door, but this is the first time I get the coffee at their stand. There are a lot more choices here. I got the mocha, which was pretty smooth. I wish the coffee flavor was just a bit stronger. the motif they put on the coffee is really pretty, I guess that's what you pay for. it's a nice treat to have coffee there. the line and the wait wasn't so bad. I also got a half lb coffee, it smells great, haven't made any yet.
author: Cicie W.

description:
I don't know what they put in their waffles, but I'd eat them everyday if I could. 
And I hate waffles.
But I love their waffles. 

...so much, I'm willing to wait 30 minutes in a line 6987242586925 people long. 

Yum.
author: Rebecca N.

description: I barely even drink coffee, but Blue Bottle is definitely an exception! I'm not quite sure what it is, but I think it has a different taste to it compared to other coffee places. I think it's cool and cute how they just brew it right in front of you in their little teapot as it drains into your cup. Blue bottle goes great with just about anything (macaroons/beignets) which I had that day exploring the Ferry Building. There's always a line so it's a can't miss! They really need to expand sooner or later.
author: Diane L.

description: The lattes are delicious. The flavor of the coffee definitely holds up against the milk, which is foamed to perfection. When I went, the barista drew the loveliest tulip into my foam. The beans are a bit pricey. The lines are outrageous. However, I definitely, definitely recommend getting coffee here if you are any sort of coffee aficionado with a bit of time to spare.
author: Koyel B.

description: Tried the drip and an espresso. I love the made-to-order manual pour over with a Hario kettle. The espresso tasted great with lovely fruity notes but I thought it was - for a double ristretto - pulled a little too short. Subsequent visits during the same trip were to the kiosks outside the build that are set up during the farmers' market. The drip coffee received did not disappoint.
author: Joe P.

description: Seriously - the line was 20 people long and this kiosk doesn't even take credit - the indoor version is better but with an even longer line - at least it takes credit.  One star off for all of that - the Mint Plaza cafe is much less crowded, they take credit, and they have food!
author: Michael U.

description: This is my happy place. Granted I'm a little biased since I come here every weekday, but this is my favourite coffee in the world. It does take a while - on average it probably takes 10-15 minutes to get my coffee. But it's totally worth it to come in a little early or leave work a little late just to make time for it. And of course, the baristas are all super friendly =)
author: Bingying L.

description: I felt like an idiot waiting in line 30 minutes for a cup of coffee! The coffee is good, but get a grip folks! I really think the line is the most significant part of the marketing for this company. I ordered a drip coffee that I drank black, it was decent, nothing more than you would get at Starbucks. Also, ordered a mocha, I would not consider it good. Go to a nearby Starbucks or better yet Peets.
author: Andrew M.

description:
In Near Eastern Studies class, I once learned that Islamic scholars made coffee haram--prohibited--because the coffee house was leading to the creation of secular meeting places.

I dont really buy that. 

But then there are times, like this one, when coffee is so damn good--as Blue Bottle is--that you sort of forget that anything, or Anything, really matters.
author: George J.

description: great coffee.  horrible service.  these employees need to get their heads out of their ass, stop smelling their own farts, and start making drinks.
author: Hagop K.

description:
Need I add a 5 star review?  

Who knew a plain drip coffee, BLACK, could be so delicious and sweet.  Needs not a drop of milk or sugar.  

This place always has a line, but well worth it.  $2.50 for a plain drip is a bit much..but it is damn good.
author: anita h.

description: I usually shy away from coffee and espresso drinks because I don't like the bitter taste (I know, I have the taste buds of a 12 year old).  BUT the mocha here is AMAZING!  It's so chocolaty and the espresso taste blends in nicely.  The chocolate doesn't cover up the taste of the espresso and I find that I don't mind it.  They have non-fat and whole milk and they always draw pretty pictures in your milk.  The coffee here is amazing but because of this the lines can be a little long.  Service is nice and speedy though so luckily they seem to move through the line fairly quickly.
author: Madeline W.

description:
Staring into the sun, in line with 27 other addicts, one has got to wonder if there's crack in the coffee. Your heart rate speeds up, flutters a bit. Like first love? Pure, sweet caffeine rushes through your blood. Intoxicating. You make eyes with another lustful consumer, eager for their fix.

What's the going rate for a cuppa joe these days? The $2 you'll fork over? Nah. Maybe the fact that you are willing to wait in a line where the end is out of sight. Fifteen, maybe twenty minutes of your time? That's much steeper than the damage it'll do to your wallet once you're hooked. Can a cup of coffee be THAT good? Smooth and hot, bitter is out of the question, an ideal date, a one night stand, perhaps. Dripped to order and sure to satisfy (long after she's done and gone).

Worth the effort?
Must be time to go back for another round to find out
author: Alissa A.

description: Waited about 15 minutes for a latte but it was worth it.  Possibly the best latte I've ever had!  Friendly staff!
author: Steve H.

description:
The coffee was better this time around, but really, how could it have been any worse than the vile cup they served me 16 months ago?

I know Blue Bottle is really popular in San Francisco (I know this because the baristas had soooo many friends chatting them up and cutting in line that I had to wait at least 20 minutes for my drink) but you guys deserve better coffee. You really do. It's so hard not to quote Public Enemy but seriously DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE.
author: Michelle B.

description: One of the best coffees I've ever had. ( : I loved the latte.
author: Anelisa L.

description:
Talk about a long line for coffee. 

One good thing about the long line is that they have a window by the counter and you can watch them make your coffee the old drip method. 

Tried some of their black coffee and their affogatto. 

Both were great, I'm not a coffee aficionado by any means but you can tell their coffee is a lot better quality. 

If I lived in the city this place would make it on my daily rotation.
author: Eric H.

description:
Why am I even telling anyone about this gem? The lines are long enough already. Oh, and this is for the Hayes Valley location, not Ferry Building.

I went here dressed in my business attire and felt waaaaaaaaay unhip. Even got some dirty looks from a bike messenger in tight jeans. The hipster factor here is off the charts, which I truthfully don't mind at all. Don't be sad mr emo guy, your tears are fogging your pseudo nerd glasses.

I got my first cup here yesterday and it's ruined me for everything else. Pete's will still be my favorite convenient cup of joe, but Blue Bottle can't be beat for flavor and quality. They  roast the beans there in the shop and make every cup fresh to order! The best cup of coffee I've ever had in America.
author: Marky M.

description:
I usually like places with a good venue, but this time this review is purely about the coffee.

This blue bottle is in the Ferry building, which itself is such a neat place to visit.  Not too much in the area, but it's on my way to Pier 38 where I work a few times a week. (dogpatch labs).

I stopped there for some food at Taylors, and then had some coffee.  The drip is amazing!  It's so strong and full of flavor.  I was an instant fan.  I love really dark and strong coffee.  This one was great.

I've only been once, I hope to go again soon!
author: Art C.

description:
THE best coffee in the city. Who cares if you wait 20-30 minutes on a Saturday morning... no one really does. As my sister would say, "Its all part of the experience." 

The New Orleans iced coffee, though not great for this cold weather, is my favorite drink. It is really strong, but with a hint of sweet too. Also the double cappachino is amazing. Really creamy and rich. 

Bring cash because at the stands for the Farmer's Market that is all they take. There are two, one counter in the front and one in the back. I find the front quicker, but like I said, don't be in a rush. Make this your new tradition every Saturday morning.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I just had it black.
From the tent next to the Ferry Market building.
It was CLEAN no thick after taste coffee..
that earned it's long line.

Definitely worth a foodie's swirl and swallow when in SF.
author: Annie P.

description:
I remember it as if it was just yesterday... My very first experience with Blue Bottle Coffee Company, and it was at this Ferry Building location. My brother was visiting from out of town, I wanted to show off some of San Francisco's finest offerings, so we decided to grab a BBCC coffee - I had heard it was good. Good? No not good. Great, yes. 

A few months later and I sit here, in front of my computer, sipping my own home-brewed cup Giant Steps manual drip coffee. I am now addicted to the BBCC crack and I absolutely love it. 

I would have given BBCC five stars, but there's always a line. The line occurs because each cup is hand-dripped for the finest taste. I don't know if there's really any way around that line, but it still sucks. Additionally, three bucks for a cup of drip coffee is steep. I guarantee you it's worth it, but regardless, it's expensive. 

Bottom line; if you have a taste for the finest, BBCC is one of the best types of coffee San Francisco (and the entire Bay Area) has to offer.
author: Jono K.

description: Could easily be the best coffee I ever had. Cool, creamy, and delish.
author: Maria M.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high. I recently went to Seattle and had some a-mazing lattes, and I felt certain Blue Bottle would measure up to the talented baristas that wowed me in WA. They fell short. My soy latte was decent, but not excellent given the time it took to get it. It was also lukewarm. Now, perhaps this makes me a coffee idiot, but I like my drinks piping hot. I know there is a risk of scalding or burning the milk when you get it superhot, but the latte that was presented to me was borderline cold. When I asked the barista if it could be made a bit hotter, he looked at me like I was a total idiot and replied, "We don't really make them that hot. I mean, I COULD remake it, but..."

So, I dunno. Maybe my desire for hot lattes means I am not a true coffee know-it-all, and therefore should stick to Starbucks or Peet's where it's less complicated.
author: Beth T.

description: The coffee rocks!!!  BUT - the lines are always so crazy they drive me away half the time.  they need more staff to keep it moving faster.
author: Steve S.

description: I love how isolated it is! it's in the corner of no where. haha It actually takes a while to get your coffee since the lines are pretty hectic, but it moves quickly. Their coffee wasn't too satisfying. it tasted like every other typical coffee shops. matter of fact, i think starbucks is even better than blue bottle coffee. but i hear that bbcc is really famous at latte art! maybe that should be the only reason why i should go back. other than that, employees didn't look too accommodating to begin with. lol
author: Christina B.

description:
I'd been told great things about Bluebottle, and so, as a coffee snob, I knew sooner or later I'd have to try it out.  The same friend who recommended Bluebottle also recommended Barefoot in San Jose.  Barefoot was a home run - sadly, Bluebottle was, at best, a double with nobody on base (more potential than substance).  

I had asked for a recommendation for a smooth, light-roasted coffee with low acids.  The guy looked confused, but, if he was confused, that didn't manage to prevent him from talking at length about qualities I hadn't asked about ("This one has subtle fruit flavors, whereas this one has hints of chocolate.")  It sorta seemed like he was hoping I'd just be impressed by his knowledge, and quit asking questions.  Mostly, he just seemed annoyed by the question.  Ultimately, even though I had commented that I was considering the Peru Norte coffee, the employee strongly recommended I get the Misty Valley - so I took his recommendation.  

There is nothing low-acid or light-roasted about the Misty Valley.  In fact, I have a dark roast at my apartment that is lighter roasted and less acidic than the Misty Valley.  Maybe the dude just thought he'd be a dick and recommend a dark roast - but, honestly, it just seems like he got confused when presented with what should have been an easy question about their coffees. 

I'm imagining Chef Tom Colicchio from Top Chef saying, "There is nothing wrong with a dark roasted coffee, but if you are going to give me a dark roast coffee, don't tell me it's a light roast."  

Of course, the real problem is, I don't even think the coffee I was recommended was even that good.  Maybe their other coffees are better, but I'll hesitate to spend the money on a pound of their coffee again.

As for the famous drip coffee from Blue Bottle?  It was good - probably even above average.  Of course it is neat that they make your cup of coffee while you wait - nonetheless, it feels like they manage to earn their high reputation off of gimmickry instead of quality.  Even if you are looking for a coffee to make your hands tremble with energy - there are better places in the Bay Area.  As another review noted - stronger is not the same thing as better.
author: Matthew H.

description: The Gibraltar is #28 on the 2010 Big Eat SF List by 7x7. While the drink is delicious, we really loved the conversation with our baristas. They were charming and smart. It seems that Blue Bottle invented the Gibraltar coffee drink, which is a teensy latte. Double espresso, milk, and a splash of foam are poured into a specific glass. Our barista told us that it might be named after the glass or might be named after hte drink...or a couple other legends. Wherever the truth lies, it was damn good coffee and I'd go back to Blue Bottle anytime.
author: Mairead R.

description: They have one of the best coffees you will ever have. I always get the New Orleans ice cream. Its so good.
author: Anthony V.

description:
I was told that I HAD to wait in this line because they were so good. 

It was a very long line but when it is sunny outside and there are so many cool people at this farmer's market to talk it isn't a big deal.
The latte was perfection! It made my frigging day yo!

Everyone that was working there were super busy but very nice, they really seemed like they were having a good time.
author: Christine S.

description: BB is a victim of its own grossly overhyped success. I have seen the quality suffer as more stands pop up all over the city. Lately my lattes have just been "okay", the baristas seem to act like they are doing us a huge favor by making our drinks and when you are shelling out  almost $5 per cup --middling is simply not acceptable.
author: aj s.

description:
If you want to escape from Starbucks and get some new caffeine in your system Try the New Orleans Ice Coffee!!

I hope they will have a bigger cup!

Friendly Staff
author: Aemar E.

description: Yum!  Best coffee in the world.  I always buy beans to take home with me when I go for a cup.  My only complaint is how long it takes - the lines are usually crazy, plus it takes a while to wait for my drip coffee... but must say, worth the wait.
author: Sam O.

description: New Orleans iced coffee the way it was intended to be.  SO good without all the acidity and harshness of hot coffee.   This is another cult type spot with growing numbers everyday.   Be prepared to wait 5 - 20 minutes for your fix.  The junkies swarm this place like a basshead on a crack dealer.   I think ritual or four barrels are easily as good if not better but that just me.  If your in the ferry building and your in need of a boost then this is your spot.   Not really worth the wait somtimes in my opinion though.
author: Duke B.

description:
Yeah, yeah, yeah...I'm a coffee aficionado (read "snob"). I spend too much time and money on it. I have a great machine at home. I order obscure beans on line. I have all the accoutrements required for the ritual. I seek the ultimate cup of joe. My usual joint starts firing up a short quad Americano when they see me walk in the door every morning. 

But epiphanies come in the damndest places (like the image of Jesus on cheese toast)...mine came in a hole-in-the-wall in an alley in Hayes Valley. 

These guys know their beans, blends, grinds...they are coffee sommeliers. They can riff on the obscure and offer advice to the newbie. ("Don't put your beans in the freezer as it dries them out.") They make a damn fine cup of coffee but it is a pain waiting in the inevitable line (and god forbid you try to get a drip at the Farmer's Market on Saturday morning...figure on at least a 20 minutes wait.) The paradox is that it does take time to make a good cup...people appreciate good coffee...a+b=c and therefore ya gotta wait.

I've had their drips, doppios, Caps, Americanos, lattes and never once have they been less than artisanal (damn...I sound like I live in Berkeley). Blue Bottle also sells beans and carries cookies from Miette Cakes (right down the block) which are terrific as well. If you're in Hayes Valley and need a mid-afternoon pick-me-up, stand in line, take a deep breath and have enjoy the best cup of coffee in town.
author: Gary C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon - they were out of beans and wouldn't be stocked until Monday morning! I was very disappointed. But their New Orleans Iced Coffee was delicious - I'm not sure if it's the Clover organic milk or what, but I don't think I can do Starbucks anymore.

Also, while their drip coffee is made as ordered and thus takes awhile to be made, the iced coffee was quick, if you can wait 10 minutes for the line.
author: Kolina T.

description: I love coffee that has that rich roasted flavor and not bitter!  I normally get a latte to dilute the bitter coffee flavor but my friend suggested me to just get the drip coffee. I got the expensive drip coffee that took forever to be served.  Took my first sip and it sucker punched my silly butt awake.  Oh yes!  This is a strong and flavorful coffee.  You don't really need to put anything in it.  If you're a coffee drinker like me and really appreciate the taste of coffee than this place would be great to try out.
author: Ying F.

description:
Now i know what the hype is all about. 

I am a coffee addict.  Or was, until I moved to the States and was forced to go cold turkey since the Americans' definition of fantastic coffee is Starbucks Morning Blend.

Five years on, I was able to count with one hand how many good coffee roasters I have visited: (1) The Prolific Oven in south bay, (2) Draeger's in the Peninsula, (3) ... 

OK.  I guess I really could've said I was able to count it with my thumb and index finger. 

The Gibraltar (which really is a latte served in a short glass) was smooth and creamy with no bitter aftertaste whatsoever, nor does it need any flavor enhancement (read: sugar) to mask the typically strong coffee taste.  

So the verdict: Blue Bottle blew the first two coffee places out of the water.  

Unfortunate because I neither live nor work near Blue Bottle.  

Fortunate because I can see myself dropping the bills in this place and these things can get pretty darn pricy.
author: Ange L.

description:
Coffee so good, oh so good.  Probably the best I've had in the area.  It wires you up in a blanket of aromatic, caffeinated goodness.  But you can get it at a few other places.

Ferry ride from Jack London Square to Ferry building, 20 min.
Walking through all the aromas of the ferry buliding, 20 min.  
Waiting in line to buy 2 bags of coffee, 47 minutes.
author: Ryan S.

description: I've heard Blue Bottle described as some of the best coffee in the U.S. Don't get me wrong - I like their coffee. The New Orleans iced coffee is fantastic and I think about getting it every time I venture into San Francisco. It's nice to sit outside  and watch the ferries while sipping it slowly. The problem is that it will sometimes take 45 minutes to an hour to get that yummy coffee and it will come in a tiny cup that costs almost $5. The wait is pretty hard - especially when there is a Peets down the hall with little to no wait. The people working there are also pretty snobby too but I've found that to be the case at most places in SF.
author: Amanda S.

description:
If you know me, it's not a stretch to guess that the first stop on my frequent trips to the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market on Saturdays is the Blue Bottle stall.

When it's my turn I order, "Quad latte, for Nancy"

When it's ready and they call my name, I tend to wave my arms, jump up and down shouting, "That's me! That's me!" like I won the lottery.  

Well, maybe I did.  Jumping Jeebus on a bicycle, that's good stuff!!!!!
author: Nancy W.

description:
I hd no idea what my office's obsession was with Blue Bottle Coffee...until of course I had one :)

Perfect but Addictive.
author: Rebecca W B.

description:
My first experience with Blue Bottle Coffee was at the Hayes Valley location.  I saw the line down the alley and thought, if people are cuing up down an alley it must be good.   I also thought anyone that would open their business down an alley must have confidence in their product.   After one cup, I knew why.   This is, simply put, the best latte I have ever had -- and I am from Seattle.   

From the austere menu, it is obvious that Blue Bottle aims to compete on quality - perfect flavor, temperature, and foam.    The service was friendly and efficient.  I've read the other complaints about slow service, but the day I went I was served quickly despite the line, and other times I have walked right up with no line.   

The best way to describe Blue Bottle to someone that hasn't been there before is to say that Blue Bottle is to Starbucks what In-n-Out is to McDonalds.   Blue Bottle has taken a wildly successful formula, and somehow improved upon it dramatically by focusing on doing one thing very well.  Keep up the good work Blue Bottle!
author: Shawn C.

description:
It may be the "best" coffee in San Francisco, but still is nothing close to the average street or hip tourist spot in Italy (literally anywhere like Florence, Rome, Venice/Lido, Capri etc). The iced coffee (New Orleans style) is refreshing, though they would score extra points if they used coffee to make the ice instead of water.

Espresso....wow strong and acidic. A ton of sugar didn't help either.

Caps are ok. I've had better in Italy.  The trick here is to go when it is bright and early, so to avoid the crowds after 10 ish or so. The wait can be horrendous for a small cup, but if you're a caffeine addict, each minute feels like hours.
author: Ken K.

description:
Poached eggs on brioche toast with butter.  OK, that's actually a two-some for $7.50, not bad at all.  Cafe au lait v. good.

What more is there to say?  Get your caffeine blood rush early and crash  by mid-morning.
author: Mandy S.

description:
I am not a coffee drinker. It makes me all gittery and my heart races, and I won't sleep at night. That being said, I love coffee. It is soooo good when done right, and Blue Bottle does it just right. 

I work at the Ferry Plaza at Saturday's market, at Rancho Gordo, and get there pretty early. Every week I allow myself one coffee (inspite of the adverse affects) as a special treat. Inspite of the wait, inspite of the heart palpatations, I don't care, life is too short to deny myself. I also think that the Saturday market crew at the cart is great. They are usually already in the weeds the moment the first coffee rolls off the line in the morning yet they maintain a gractious, fun-lovin' , and cool attitude throughout the day, rain or shine. 

NOTHING is better than walking fast back to the RG stand, dodging tourists and dedicated market shoppers alike, while taking that first creamy, coffee-y, delicious mouthful of heaven. I look forward to it every week.

Thanks guys!
author: sarah k.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee Company has been doing their little coffee cart at the Saturday Farmers Market for some time.  Their coffee is so good.  Each order is brewed on the spot, even drip coffee so you know each cup is SUPER Fresh.  Some people become anxious because it takes a little longer to get your coffee but they don't understand their order is made just for them.  If they don't care about coffee being fresh, they can just go inside to Peets (which is fine coffee too of course) but waiting for a blue bottle order is worth it if you Lurve a good cup o' joe.  Go with a companion and wait for your coffee sitting in the sun enjoying the people watching and taking in the bay breeze.  Now doesn't that sound lovely?  Well it is.  Check it out.  

The guys who work at blue bottle are also very friendly and cool.  Tip them!
author: James M.

description: Strong strong coffee. Almost too strong for a hangover, but then again, I am not much of a coffee drinker. Kicks you in the butt, but this could just be what you are looking for. Tastes purely strong.
author: Taylor M.

description:
As far as I know, this is the only place in San Francisco to get a cappuccino like this. Micro-foamed milk is a perfect consistency and a true compliment to tasty coffee beans. If you prefer easily accessible tastes a la Starbucks, this may be too much coffee for you. For the rest of us, it's what coffee should taste like, and I wish more places cared as much about the art of coffee as Blue Bottle does.

Beware of one thing: getting a cup of Blue Bottle anywhere besides a Blue Bottle stand may disappoint you. It seems the best baristas work for the stands, and although the beans at partnership restaurants like Piccino in Dog Patch are the same, the results are different.
author: Timothy P.

description: Tried the New Orleans style iced coffee which was all the rage on Yelp here.  The coffee is pulled with the beans grounded right before each drink is made, so freshness is optimal.  They use regular milk for their coffee which makes it less sweet.  Gave me the caffeine jitters afterwards.  I guess I got exactly what I paid for.
author: Christine H.

description:
like most people, i enjoy my daily caffeine fix.  i'm not a coffee fanatic and many times a cup of instant coffee will do the trick. however, blue bottle coffee co. in san francisco makes you appreciate the differences in fine coffee.  aside from the great coffee, the coolest thing is the leaf they make with the coffee and milk.

favorites: try a latte and splurge for the made to order caramelized belgian waffle
author: Robert R.

description:
This place is pure comedy. 

Tourists line up in herds to have coffee served to them by a gaggle of penned in hipsters. The tourists watch hipsters like people watch animals in a zoo. 

My personal favorite is the hipster barista scowl, and in close second is the ambivalent "this coffee takes forever to make because we are part of the slow food movement."

Hi-friggin-larious.
author: sean k.

description:
I think I'm alone now...(to paraphrase)

Am I the only one who recognizes the emperor's new clothes when she sees or in this case tastes them?? Really?? This is good coffee? You got some splaining to do Blue Bottle, yes you surely do. Give me Ritual or Farley's any day over this over-hyped less than average cuppa. Have we talked about how good Philz is? Not hot enough, but good.

Plus, it's not hot enough!
author: Rachel M.

description: I love Blue Bottle Coffee! Good thing it's a Muni ride away from where I live or I'd be spending a lot of money here. I think the drinks are kind of expensive (4.75 for a mocha, 3.75 for a new orleans iced coffee) but worth it if you want to treat yourself to GOOD coffee. The coffee is so smooth and fresh, and the drinks that I've tried so far (the two listed above) are sweet enough to add flavor but not too syrupy and gross like a lot of other coffee places. Next time I will try a "real" coffee drink like a cappuccino to really appreciate their espresso.
author: Jacqueline K.

description: I am a fan.....coffee heaven....try the Gibraltar or New Orleans Iced! The lines are long, so patience goes a LONG way.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Their line can get ridiculously long and so can the wait. Since their coffee is made to order, drip by drip. Their cappuccino or mocha are made with fancy decor on top which is a nice touch. 
We had their espresso shot, which had the nice strong bitter taste it should.
Overall, well worth the long wait.
author: Annie D.

description:
Finally! A company that truly understands the value of sculpting espresso drinks THE RIGHT WAY! They know how to dose, tamp, and pull their shots to perfection. I always get a Macchiato (marked coffee). This drink is a work of art when any of the Blue Bottle Baristi prepare one of my drug of choice.

The lines (yes two) are usually long, but if I hear you complaining, I'll give you Sparkly Eyes!
author: Mark P.

description:
The. Waffle. Is. Heaven. Sent.

But of course it's a $9 fuffy and airy waffle, just like my airy wallet.

Coffee is great of course, but I usually buy my roasted beans to go. Gimme some props for expediting the coffee line, mmmkay?
author: Cathy H.

description:
Sorry I don't think its as good as Philz's .  

PS- The Minuses:-

One size small cups-- could probably use 2 to make a regular size.

Only one type of brew available.

They didn't have soy milk.

Phil was not there to talk about the coffee flavor!

THE PLUS- The guy was right- I'd "be shaking with one cup!"
author: Arissa C.

description: First time I actually paid three dollars for a small cup of coffee (here in the States).  (Shrugs.)  It was okay.  Took a while to make.  And the woman making the coffee did not seem like a morning person.  Ah, well.  I've had the experience.
author: Poet D.

description: Looking at the other reviews, there's nothing much I can add.  We split a waffle and each had a cafe mocha.  The mocha had that great chocolate from the choclatier in SF.  We live in a town that doesn't have anything like this, so we enjoyed the coffee and waffle even more.
author: Andy L.

description:
For someone who doesn't drink coffee this is pretty good. I like that they use a great amount of the coffee itself to make my cup. It really makes a difference when you're being taken to the Farmer's market early in the morning [C'mon noon is early!] but would rather sleep. 

My one complaint is that they seem to run out of half & half. 

Stop trying to give me milk as a substitute. That tiny cup needs something more potent especially if its such a tiny thing.
author: Rebekah K.

description:
Yum yum yum yum yum.  I wonder if they are schooled in the the way of the Vivace coffee because their espresso production seems to follow the specific way they do it up there.  This is no bad thing because the final product is delightful.

I am very particular about my coffee, I'd rather drink good drip than bad espresso so there are few places that I will drink a latte from and even fewer that I would espresso.  Blue Bottle I will happily allow to caffienate me in any way they choose (except for tea) but special mention has to go for the New Orleans style Iced Coffee which is a heady blend of coffee, chicory, sugar and milk that gives you not only a decent caffiene hit but backs it up with a sugar high.  I believe it is the coffee equivalent of smoking crack and injecting heroin, although you'd have to ask someone who has lived a little closer to the edge than me to confirm that.

For more daily pursuits the latte and espresso are really really good, it is a good sign when a queue of 10 people takes 20 minutes to dissipate because it means the Barista is preparing each shot and steaming the milk individually, the only way of guaranteeing a good microfoam.
author: Tony S.

description:
Maybe I shouldn't have gotten mine black.

Mom was very impressed, and I thought it was just fine, but I wasn't wowed. Then again, I'm not sure if I know what kind of coffee would wow me. I'm a Dunkin' Donuts coffee drinker.
author: Nick B.

description:
Oh Blue Bottle you are soooooo delicious and even though I often drink decaf because I just really shouldn't get all hopped up on goofballs, you make me want to mainline you.  The wait just makes me crave you more.  Sweet precious wackjob inducing nectar of the gods....

Does anyone remember that Simpsons when Grandpa is watching the kids while Marge and Homer are at the Marriage Retreat?
Grampa: (Pours Lisa a cup of coffee) Sugar?
Lisa: (Nervous) Yes, ten please.
Bart: (Rattlin') Hey Grampa, top me off!
Grampa: Are you sure your Ma let you kids drink coffee?
Bart: FOR THE LAST TIME, YES!!!!

Clearly they were waiting for Blue Bottle Coffee.  Yes the wait is LOOOOONG, but you're at a farmer's market, so it isn't like you can't go do something else while you're waiting.  The important thing is that ITS THE BEST COFFEE EVER.  I love love love their drip coffee.  And then I buy beans to go for the whole week.  Go there this Saturday.  DO IT.
author: amy l.

description:
I worked for Peet's for more than two years as a barista and always thought our coffee was the best and that I made super excellent foam. Then I tried Blue Bottle and found I didn't know shit. This is the best coffee I've ever had. (Sorry, Peet's. I still happily go to you because I live in LA and Blue Bottle doesn't exist here.)

The lines at the farmers market stands are always long, but they're worth the wait. The baristas are really patient and go out of their way to make sure you get the drink you want. I ordered a soy mocha last time, and the man who took my order offered me regular or dairy free chocolate, in case I was lactose intolerant. Super thoughtful!
author: Joanna L.

description:
Admittedly, I had to dock the star because of the line... If its possible to be too popular then this might be a good example.

That said I've never walked away from the long lines, rather I wait patiently because that stuff is too good.

New Orleans Iced Coffee is superbly delish... order two, one without ice and put it in the fridge for an afternoon fix. Keeps great even with the milk in it.

Three Africans -- when they drip this on Tuesday mornings, oh my! I have not had a better cup of coffee. Ever. Giant Steps is a very close second.

Cheers!
author: Ryan F.

description: Long wait. But really good coffee. Cafe mocha was really good.
author: E A.

description:
i know blue bottle doesn't need anymore reviews of people raving, but i just have to put in my 2 cents.

i rarely drink coffee, but am weirdly particular about it still.  iced coffee is usually my drink of choice, but i hate it when it's watery. i dislike starbucks, but really like peet's.

and I REALLY LOVE blue bottle. new orlean's iced ... is.. like.. CRACK. not kidding. so freakin' delicious and makes me a little crazy due to the chicory but ... i fall in love every time i drink it.  and that is a strong statement.
author: Linda T.

description: Honestly people, it's a bit hyped. Yes it's good coffee but the lines and coffee snobbery are silly. I am more of a fan of Capricorn coffee in the SF and in LA, Blue Bottle is no match for either Groundworks or Intelligista. Just sayin.
author: Scott M.

description: Coming from Seattle I like to pretend I'm a learned coffee snob. However, Blue Bottle is making it easy for everyone in SF to know just what absolutely amazing coffee should taste like.  In a city with a lot of noteworthy coffee, Blue Bottle is the best.  I don't know if it's the beans they pick, the way they roast 'em, or their brewing process but everything seems perfect.
author: Ivan L.

description:
True coffee artisans.

One of the most INSANE cups of coffee I've ever had and my wife's latte was great as well.

Made via the "brew bar" with fresh grounds, ceramic filter holder, stirring, and water at just the right temp, these guys have it down.  Coffee was strong, yet flavorful and smooth. 

Coffee from here was an experience like no other.

Plus, you are in the food-mecca of the ferry-building, so you are overwhelmed with the art of great food.
author: Patrick G.

description: I hail from New York, where coffee is good, but not in Midtown East (where I work and need it the most).  Coming to San Francisco opened my eyes to a place where Starbucks exists, but people acknowledge that it's garbage.  I had multiple soy lattes at Blue Bottle during my trip to the West Coast, each one better than the next.  And these people are so nice, to boot!  My first time here I had no cash, the line to order was insane, but the barista took my order anyway and told me to pop back in to pay after hitting up the ATM.  The timing was perfect - as I handed her my money, she handed me an epiphany in a recycled cup.  Thank you, BBC - you're even better than the network.
author: Katherine B.

description:
I have been less satisfied with Blue Bottle since they went "official" and took out permanent space in the Ferry Building.  For some reason, their onsite brew consistently has a little edge of bad bitterness (as opposed to good bitterness) in it.  I don't have the vocabulary or technical expertise to pinpoint it, but it's almost that stale taste, even though you see them making it fresh.

I will still give it three stars for the quality of their take-out beans and their unique specialty mocha.  But it's in the same building as Peets and I probably won't go exclusively to either one.
author: Danny H.

description: good coffee. find it.
author: Sam V.

description: Blue Bottle is a gem of San Francisco, its worth waiting in line if you're at the Ferry Bldg.  I ask for mine extra hot so it doesn't cool off while it steeps.  Its also great.  Their coffee between 5th & 6th is also great, sweet bldg, nice baristias, and exotic coffee siphon machines that look like turn of the century chemistry experiments, but they make damn good coffee!
author: Chris R.

description:
Yeah, the line can be long at the big kiosk at the Farmer's Market (the other kiosk, near the front door of the Ferry Building, has a shorter wait) but it's always worth the wait.  Just standing there listening to random visitors and tourists marvel at the latte art the baristas make for every latte they pour is pure entertainment.  "Wow, it's like art!  There's a leaf in my coffee!"  But don't get me wrong, the latte art is cool.

But what I really dig about these folks is how into coffee they are.  The cute gal that's often stir stir stirring the drip coffees was kind enough to tell me exactly how I should make the same stuff at home, and it's opened my eyes since.  (Okay, bad pun.)  And there's something to be said about the fact that they sell beans so fresh you can't actually even use them right away when you get home.

Grab an espresso, grab a camera, offer your friend a sip, and make sure to take a pic of their reaction.  Pure gold in a cup.
author: Chuck W.

description:
scrumptious.  i got a macchiato and it was perfect.
the only coffee that i prefer more is stumptown.
author: renee m.

description:
Yes, another coffee review. What can I say- I'm an addict.

I love, love, love, my Saturday morning Farmer's Market double cappucino !!! This is the BEST coffee in the entire state- I've never had a bad capp here. There is always a long line of people who are in the know but these guys are  fast so the wait isn't too bad. It's definitely worth it. 

I love this stuff so much I sometimes come back for a second one. BZZZZZZZZZZ
author: None o.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee beans rock!!! 
Order them online and you get your order  on Monday to your door. You can also pick it up at the Ferry Building (Tues/Sat) or at the coffee kiosk in Hayes Valley (Daily).
author: Deno M.

description: Ok, been walking over here almost everyday. I'm sure everyone notices the long lines here on both sides. It was a nice hot day and i decided to try the New Orleans iced coffee it was good. I'm not sure if i'm sold on it yet i'll need to try the drip and iced coffee again. Boy is this place busy tho people in and out buying bags of coffee.
author: Larry L.

description: So please don't kill me, but I'm not so into Blue Bottle, which happens to be the coffee darling of SF.  I tried the New Orleans coffee and the regular latte after having waited a long while in line.  Both (at separate times and places) were very intense, which I like, but kind of sour in taste. Maybe I have to try it again but I wasn't super impressed.
author: Terry K.

description: I love blue bottle! smooth coffee, revived me after a yucky morning.
author: Sherry H.

description: If I were simply rating the coffee itself, I would've given Blue Bottle 4 stars. It was strong and oily which is what a good cup of coffee should be. Unfortunately a 30 minute wait for an 8oz cup of coffee simply doesn't work for me. Enough said.
author: Remy B.

description: Get the New Orleans Iced Coffee. It's incredible!
author: Robyn B.

description:
There's a reason for the long lines at Blue Bottle...

I used to be primarily a tea drinker but blue bottle turned me to the dark side.  Now, I'm an ADDICT.  You will find me waiting on long lines at one of the blue bottle kiosks to get my fix.  

The individually dripped coffee is rich and aromatic...and no after taste.  I'm usually bouncing off the walls after a cup but I don't care.  It's just too good to pass.

I got my family & friends hooked too.  :)

I've considered buying 'The Three African' coffee bags and just leave them around my apt as aromatic air freshers.  It smells SO GOOD!

They give me free coffee when I bought multiple bags at the Ferry Building stall last time.
author: Lis A.

description:
You know you're addicted to good espresso when you drive out of your way to wait in a line for your coffee before commuting to Marin.  I can't stand the espresso near me, so I go to Blue Bottle.

I love to see people with their coffees sitting on the curb of an alley... so hilarious.  It says a lot for the quality of the product if people are willing to do that.

I love Ritual as well, but their place is loud and super crowded, so this is a quiet change from that.  It's good for a jolt on the go.  I don't think I'd want to sit on the curb, personally.

The baristas are VERY nice, and that wins uber points in my book.

I will say I wasn't impressed by their hor chocolate.  It was a little cold and watery.  Maybe a fluke.
author: Aaron W.

description: I'm hesitating to write this based on the gushing reviews, but my latte was barely warm ... Almost cool ... And was definitely fine, but nothing that would inspire the orgiastic comments seen ... Maybe an off day?  Counter person who took my cash was very peppy and pleasant ... I'll give it another try on my next visit ... Am I missing something?
author: Paul W.

description: Not the greatest coffee....not sure what all the fuss with that drip is. Very bland tasting.
author: Cristina P.

description:
If it's 75 degrees outside, and there is still a long-ass line for this coffee, you know it's damn good.

Pros:
-So freakin fresh.  Had the drip coffee and they individually brew each cup.  The taste was smooth (don't like acidic coffee) and deep.
-The staff are cute and friendly
-Only $2.00 for deeelicious coffee.  I've paid $3.50 for equally good coffee.

Cons:
-Long lines
 
Bottomline:  It's awesome.  The end.
author: Liezl C.

description: Should have taken note of previous review and gone outside of Ferry Bldg. to have Blue Bottle. No matter, the wait wasn't so bad and it gave me time to run outside and buy some great pastries to go along with what I hoped would be great coffee. Not disappointed, best drip coffee ever and silky smooth mocha. The baristas are like monks and the coffee preparation their religion. I felt that respectful observation, a soft thank you, and a small nod were proper tokens of gratitude to appease these coffee gods!
author: Jason J.

description:
The coffee is expensive (2.75) for what you get. The taste borders bitter and almost watered down.
Hopefully, blue bottle doesn't go the way of peets but it's getting there. Losing its mission statement.
author: maverick s.

description: Barf. There is a lot of hype about Blue Bottle, but I just don't taste it. I've been a few times at the Ferry Building, and I am not a fan of the flavor. The employees seem to really care about their craft, and that's great. But the product doesn't taste very deep to me, and I don't want a latte or a cup of coffee to taste watered down. Especially when I have to wait in line for half an hour on a Saturday morning.
author: Adriana A.

description:
This review pertains to the 66 Mint Street location.

(-)
'Tude from the staff is definitely not appreciated, but I can empathize with them because they're so f'n busy. Super picky clientele does not help matters, nor does the clusterf*ck that is the order/serving counter.  Many people swear by Blue Bottle and it is a Google "favorite place." Because of these things, the coffee may be excellent, but the experience is generally not - they're a victim of their own success.

If you're from out of town and for some reason still don't own a GPS and are trying to figure out why you can't make any left-hand turns and would like a temporary bit of respite while observing a microcosm of SF cliches AND/OR have 20 min to wait for coffee, please drop on by.

(+)
Everything I have tried there is the tastiest example of the beverage. Their brioche is also delicious. Gentrification of SoMA is good. They pour foam/cream in the shape of a perfect trilobite and they have some of the coolest coffee-making contraptions you'll ever see. Newspapers on Kendo swords. If they moved the serving counter to the opposite end of the counter (or equiv) I would give them at least another star.
author: Brian D.

description: While I was overwhelmed and a bit underwhelmed by the ferry building (so many tourists!), I loved the coffee here.  I ordered at their convenient little side window, so avoided the line.  Yummy strong expresso, just the way it's supposed to be.
author: Lina B.

description:
Folks, reality check time: this is coffee.

You should not have to wait in line for 20 minutes to order your coffee, then wait while it is made. 

With that said, I HAD to see what all the fuss was about, so I waited in line for 20 minutes just to order my espresso. 

The espresso was good. Not bright like a proper Italian espresso, and made with a darker roast. But it was smooth and sweet, very good flavor. I do like the brightness of Italian espresso, so this was not my favorite, but I watched the barristas make up some nice looking coffee drinks. That is clearly the draw here: mochas and whatnot.  But I will say that from the espresso, you can tell that they are selecting good beans and they know what they are doing with regard to roasting.

So, in the end, Blue Bottle is brilliant because they have slowed down the entire coffee making process in order to form ridiculously long lines which only makes people want their coffee that much more. Induced demand. Like I said, brilliant. And, good coffee. With a normal line, I'd be back. But, based on their fans, I won't hold my breath for a shorter line any time soon.
author: Channon H.

description:
Only been there once and loved it...but have had it with a splash or two of vodka at NOPA several times. Great tasting coffee...and it's not Starbucks, so you gotta love it. 

Side note:  The fact that I drink Starbucks everyday doesn't mean anything. They are on every freakin' corner of the FiDi. I'm forced to go there...or resort to Peet's crazy strong coffee. Oh, there is Madeline's too, but they don't take credit for purchases less than $10. :(
author: Deann M.

description:
Coffee that is dripped just for your cup--awesome.

Sitting outside and watching the ships--fabulous.

Just an overall great coffee place, and the location helps also :)
author: garbanzo b.

description:
I kinda gave up on Blue Bottle Coffee after I had their latte some time ago because it didn't 'wow' me, and it was around the same time I discovered Philz (truly addictive stuff).  But this weekend at the Ferry Building my friend and I were craving coffee, so I decided to give BB another chance.  Afterall, I was told the New Orleans iced coffee was worth a try.  And I think I'm in love with the iced coffee; however, not as much in love with it as I am with Philz's Tantalizing Turkish.  

The iced coffee was strong and smooth. No need for added sugar, just a splash of milk will do. 

I loved the tag-team thing the baristas had going on to get the orders out quickly, especially since the long was constantly growing. 

Now I must come back to try the drip coffee.
author: Lisa C.

description: The New Orleans Style Iced Coffee, is a must! Best coffee I have ever had and I was born and raised near Seattle, we know coffee.
author: Ashley B.

description: If you don't mind standing in a line that takes 20-30 minutes to get your coffee... this is the place for you!  Their coffee is delish  (especially the new orleans style chicory coffee)  Very very good.  The downsides is that they couldn't make espresso drinks that day we went.. no lattes, mochas, cappuchinos.. must get their belgain waffle.  They make it fresh and it comes out it's so hot you can't hold it!  So good.
author: Margie C.

description: new orleans iced coffee, fog, ferry building, view of the bridge.  need i say more?
author: Ally E.

description:
i had to find out what all of the hype was about. i've walked past this stand at the ferry plaza numerous times and the length of the line scared me away. who would be crazy enough to stand in a line of 20+ people and then wait for who knows how long just for a cup of coffee?! 

well, this time, i was crazy enough. even as i stood in line for 10+ minutes just to place my order and pay for my drink, i was skeptical as to whether i was wasting 10 minutes of my life for something not really worth waiting for. i stood there watching them make each cup of regular coffee with the "pour over method" and thinking, that is just the most inefficient method i have ever seen, how could that possibly be worth it?

guess what? the coffee is fantastic. rich, bold and strong. so, if you're one of those weaklings who like watery starbucks coffee, i don't think this coffee is for you. if you like peet's, this may be right up your alley. this blows peet's coffee out of the water.

make note that there is a "Rear" line as well that seems like it's probably a bit shorter than the line in the "main" area of the plaza.

Bought a 1/2 pound bag to take home with me  (cost is somewhere around $8) and can't wait to try it. Note that it is only sold as whole bean so make sure you have a way to grind it before you purchase it.
author: Amy T.

description:
everyone raves about the coffee but I would point out the food here is actually quite good.  the sandwiches here are really tasty - range from 4-6 bucks.  I had the egg salad and turkey - rarely do either of those sandwich options get me amped but they were particularly well-done here with unique twists - egg salad had cornichons and turkey added shaved celery and chevre.

the only neg on this place is that I am pretty sure their employees take horse tranquilizers before they come to work.  super nice, but total space cadets -  blue bottle invented the phrase "slow food."
author: Anthony L.

description: Holy cow the line can be so long sometimes! I took that as a sign to go with Blue Bottle over Peets (which I'm quite fond of). They seem to take great care with every cup they make, making it take a while to order/pay. I love the no fuss no muss, no froo froo drinks.
author: Angie Q.

description:
I'm from Seattle, so I like my coffee.  I've heard lots of hype about Blue Bottle since I moved to San Francisco, and from what I've had, they deserve that hype.

I had a latte, which was the best latte I've had since moving to San Francisco.  The wait in the later afternoon was not bad at all.

I'm planning on going back to try out some of their drip coffee that everyone raves about.
author: Josh S.

description:
this is one of the things you need to try if you're a tourist in SF.

i got a mocha here... waited about 20 minutes for it. The barista took his time in preparing the beverage and the beverage turned out very well :) however, i don't think it's worth the price and wait for it, to be honest.
author: Daisy J.

description:
5 stars for coffee and baristas.
3 stars for order process, it could be smoother without compromising- also it only takes 10 or so people in front of you to make this take a very long time.

In the end - who cares about service, really, the coffee rocks.
author: Justin M.

description: Oh my gosh this place is beyond the horizons in its goodness. The new Orleans iced coffee is ridiculously good with the chicory and milk. The mocha is also a killer made with local tcho chocolate. Even the simple misto or drip coffee are so superior to any other place. The guy behind the counter said it was all in the extraction process. I don't mind waiting in long lines this place is so good.
author: Caitlin Z.

description: still lovin' BB coffee. Love the lattes, cappuccino, new orleans and gibraltars. It's always perfect. I don't know how they do it, but I def admire the baristas' love and time spent on making each cup. If the line is too long in front of the ferry building, they have another stand behind it as well on Saturdays.
author: Jessica h.

description:
Service: 4
Value: 4
Coffee: 4
The lines are always long at the Farmer's Market and there's a reason for that.   Good and strong coffee.  The employees always bust their ass trying to serve people as fast as possible.  The wait is always 10-15 from the time you get in line to the time you get your coffee, so just be patient.
author: Roger H.

description:
I'm reviewing the kiosk when you walk into the building...not the one outside the building....

Yes, the lines are long. Are they worth the wait? Depends if you're looking for great coffee or customer service.

Coffee was great, per usual. Customer Service... the girl with the glasses that works there is super sweet... I think they can move a little bit quicker though. Yes, I understand espresso making is an art..but seriously....
author: mister b.

description:
Two and a half.  Five stars for the coffee, but it's only fair that I cut that in half since no matter which location I go to, they consistently only fill my cup up halfway.  Okay, 2/3, but the top 1/3rd of the cup is wider.  Therefore, halfway.

If I'm paying $2.75 for a 12 oz cup of drip coffee, there better be more than 6 oz of coffee in it.  If you're drinking Blue Bottle coffee and putting half a cup of cream in it, you're doing it wrong!
author: Jeff S.

description: great, strong iced coffee. the way it should be without being bitter.  very well balanced. walked through farmers market yesterday and grabbed a cup of iced coffee to go. even though it is pre-sweetened, it is not too sweet.  you can choose your milk. definitely would go back again for more!
author: Nicole R.

description: Upon arriving in SF, I was told I MUST try Blue Bottle Coffee Co., as it is the best coffee in the Bay Area. As a coffee snob, I knew it was certainly a must-see... the little cafe inside the Ferry Building was crowded, per usual, but the staff was patient and managed the lines without any hassles. All beverages come in one size, no syrups or fancy fixings like Starbucks, but the simplicity is what highlights how truly deliciously wonderful the coffee is. I ordered a nonfat latte, and watched as the barista decorated my latte with a feathery, foamed shape. The foam was perfect and thick like meringue, and the espresso shots were sweet, caramel-rich, and dense. Definitely did NOT disappoint! All must try Blue Bottle Coffee Co. when in SF. :-)
author: Emily T.

description: My review is for buying whole beans only.  I haven't tried any of their drinks or food items.  Their beans are so fresh and taste great when brewed at home. I also love this location because I get to walk around and check out the other vendors in the Ferry Building.  Also, the Blue Bottle staff is always nice!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Blue Bottle is the best coffee in the Bay Area.  Probably the best coffee in the US (I'll admit, I haven't tried them all).  Yes, long lines.  Yes, not the cheapest.  But worth the $ and the wait.  

If you are visiting from out of town, definitely try it.  You'll likely to end up ordering their beans online and making the best espresso you've ever had at home.
author: Alexander K.

description:
Best. Coffee. EVER. Oh my god, every time I go to San Francisco over a weekend, I always plan a visit to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market on Saturday morning to get a cup (ok, well, it's usually two in the end) of this amazing coffee.

They brew it fresh in front of you, as you order it. There is usually a line, but take a friend and the wait will fly by while you enjoy the morning chatting and deciding what to get for breakfast from the market stalls once you have your coffee. 

It's a $2 cup, which is more than most places for what is conventionally considered a "small", but it's worth every penny! :o)
author: Julie F.

description:
A wise person once said to me:  "This is the only place where you'll pay $3 for a cafe au lait, wait in line for 20 minutes, and still leave wanting more."  I'd have to agree,  cause I do it every dammed weekend.  

There can only be one explanation...

Heroin in the coffee...?
author: Sarah J.

description: tasty, hand crafted bean juice. well worth the wait. do it damnit!
author: Monika K.

description:
Blue Bottle at the Ferry Building is a unique experience in high-end coffee.  On the one hand you have the pedigree of Blue Bottle while on the other you have the extreme volume demands of the Ferry Building.  To some extent these factors are at odds with each other: excellent coffee is something that requires both time and attention to detail.  Certainly this reality is no different than what is faced by the other vendors at the Ferry Building, however, and the quality of the Ferry vendors are generally top-notch despite the bustle the building receives.  

First off, Blue Bottle overall isn't my favorite coffee roaster in the Bay area, but it definitely high quality and may suit the preferences of other peoples' palettes better than mine.  I prefer lighter roast coffee and, in general, Blue Bottle's coffees tend to be roasted a little darker than you'll find at Ritual, Four Barrel, or Barefoot.  Most of their offerings are a good solid medium-roast with a few lighter single-origins here and there.  As a result you'll find coffee with a lot of body and flavors that gravitate more towards earthy, cocoa notes than bright citrus or vegetable.  Most of the posted cupping notes are written emphasizing the emotions evoked by and histories of the coffee more than specific flavor notes.  This is unusual in the SF scene and is endearing, but it can make choosing beans that match your taste preferences more challenging than it should be.  BB also seems to heavily favor its blends, which are very popular throughout the city, over its single-origin beans.  The shop has two 'sides' pulling different coffees at the same time: the shop's blend, Hayes Valley, is up front while a rotating single-origin espresso is available around the corner.  Having the choice between the two is really neat but I think most of the crowds miss the distinction and go to whichever side they notice first (or whichever has the shorter line).  It's a shame because when Blue Bottle gets single-origin right it's a beautiful thing and I do think there's a missed opportunity for coffee education in their minimalist approach.

The Ferry Building used to pull a different espresso, which I greatly preferred over the current Hayes Valley blend.  Hayes was made for the location in Hayes Valley for which it is named.
